questions.text: Horizontally, mammary gland is extended upto mid axillary line in which of the following intercostal space?
questions.solution:
Extent of the mammary gland:

  • The breast lies in the superficial fascia of the pectoral region.
  • Vertically, it extends from the second to the sixth ribs.
  • Horizontally, it extends from the lateral border of the sternum to the midaxillary line in 4th intercostal space.

Reference: B.D.Chaurasia's Human Anatomy, 8th Edition, Volume - 1, Page No - 3

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy with mental retardation, dysostosis multiplex, coarse facial features, clear cornea. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The mucopolysaccharidoses (MPSs) usually inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, with Hurler and Hunter syndromes being perhaps the most widely studied. None is common. In general, these conditions are chronic and progressive and affect multiple organs. Many patients exhibit organomegaly (eg, hepato- and splenomegaly; severe abnormalities in the development of cartilage and bone; abnormal facial appearance; and mental retardation. In addition, defects in hearing, vision and the cardiovascular system may be present.

In Hurlers clinical features are Mental retardation, coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, cloudy cornea.

In Hunter's disease cloudy cornea is absent, Diagnostic tests include analysis of GAGs in urine or tissue biopsy samples; assay of suspected defective enzymes in white blood cells, fibroblasts or serum; and test for specific genes. Prenatal diagnosis is now sometimes possible using amniotic fluid cells or chorionic villus biopsy samples.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, Page no 638-639

choices.text: B fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than B fibers.
A fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers.
C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers.
Sensory nerves are nearer the bone than motor nerves and hence are less affected by pressure.

questions.text: A man falls into a deep sleep with one arm under his head. This arm is paralyzed when he awakens, but it tingles, and pain sensation in it is still intact. The reason for the loss of motor function without loss of pain sensation is:
questions.solution:
• A fibers are myelinated nerve fibers responsible for transmitting signals related to touch, pressure, and proprioception. They are involved in fast, sharp pain sensation.
  • C fibers are unmyelinated nerve fibers responsible for transmitting signals related to dull, aching pain and temperature.

When the man falls into a deep sleep with one arm under his head, the pressure on the nerves can affect the myelinated A fibers (responsible for motor function and touch/pressure sensation) more than the unmyelinated C fibers (responsible for pain sensation). As a result, the motor function is affected (arm is paralyzed) due to the pressure on the A fibers, while the pain sensation remains intact, as the C fibers are less sensitive to pressure.

Reference: Ganong's Review Of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Page no 85-97

choices.text: Acetylation of lysine residues leads to chromatin condensation
High levels of DNA methylation in gene regulatory elements leads to transcriptional silencing
Histone marks on inactive genes enable DNA compaction into heterochromatin

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding histone organisation?
questions.solution:
Lysine residues are acetylated by histone acetyltransferases (HATs), whose modifications tend to open the chromatin and increase transcription. In turn, these changes can be reversed by histone deacetylases (HDACs), leading to chromatin condensation.

Option A: Unlike genetic changes, many epigenetic alterations (e.g., histone acetylation and DNA methylation) are reversible and amenable to therapeutic intervention.

Option C: High levels of DNA methylation in gene regulatory elements typically result in transcriptional silencing. Like histone modifications, DNA methylation is tightly regulated by methyltransferases, demethylating enzymes, and methylated-DNA-binding proteins.

Option D: Actively transcribed genes in euchromatin are associated with histone marks that make the DNA accessible to RNA polymerases. In contrast, inactive genes have histone marks that enable DNA compaction into heterochromatin.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 3-4

questions.text: Which of the following action is expected on stimulation of muscarinic receptors?
questions.solution:
Muscarinic Actions

  • Male sex organs: Due to vasodilation, the cholinergic system is responsible for erection of the male organ.
  • Heart: Parasympathetic system has inhibitory effect on the heart (M2) and is responsible for the negative chronotropic (decreased heart rate) and dromotropic (decreased conduction) effects. Bradycardia occurs.
  • Blood vessels: No direct cholinergic supply is present in blood vessels but cholinergic receptors (M3) are present on endothelium of blood vessels. Stimulation of these receptors causes release of NO from endothelium resulting in vasodilation. Additional mechanism of vasodilation is inhibitory action of ACh on noradrenaline release from tonically active vasoconstrictor nerve endings.
  • Eye: Cholinergic system stimulates sphincter pupillae (circular muscle of eye) and thus results in miosis (M3). ACh also causes contraction of ciliary muscle of the eye and thus accommodation is possible. Anticholinergic drugs result in mydriasis and loss of accommodation (blurred vision).
  • Glands: Cholinergic system stimulates the secretion of glands and results in the increased salivation, lacrimation as well as sweating (M3). On the other hand anticholinergic drugs will result in dry mouth, dry eyes and difficulty in swallowing (due to decreased saliva).
  • Urinary bladder: Cholinergic drugs stimulate detrusor and relax the trigone (sphincter) of urinary bladder resulting in increased micturition (M3). Anticholinergic drugs may result in urinary retention.
  • Gastrointestinal tract: Hydrochloric acid secretion in the stomach (M1 and M3) is stimulated by the parasympathetic system and thus increases the risk of peptic ulcer disease. Peristalsis of GIT is increased and sphincters are relaxed by the cholinergic drugs. Anticholinergic drugs can be used as spasmolytic agents for intestinal colic.
  • Bronchus: Cholinergic system causes bronchoconstriction (M3) and anticholinergic drugs may lead to bronchodilation.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no 114

questions.text: Absence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the affected side indicates:
questions.solution:
ABNORMALITIES OF PUPILLARY REACTIONS

  1. Amaurotic light reflex. It refers to the absence of direct light reflex on the affected side (say right eye) and absence of consensual light reflex on the normal side (i.e., left eye). This indicates lesions of the optic nerve or retina on the affected side (i.e., right eye), leading to complete blindness. In diffuse illumination both pupils are of equal size.
  2. Efferent pathway defects. Absence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the affected side (say right eye) and presence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the normal side (i.e., left eye) indicates efferent pathway defect (sphincter paralysis). Near reflex is also absent on the affected side. Its causes include: effect of parasympatholytic drugs (e.g., atropine, homatropine), internal ophthalmoplegia, and third nerve paralysis.
  3. Wernicke's hemianopic pupil. It indicates lesion of the optic tract. In this condition light reflex (ipsilateral direct and contralateral consensual) is absent when light is thrown on the temporal half of the retina of the affected side and nasal half of the opposite side; while it is present when the light is thrown on the nasal half of the affected side and temporal half of the opposite side.
  4. Marcus Gunn pupil. It is the paradoxical response of a pupil of light in the presence of a relative afferent pathway defect (RAPD). It is tested by swinging flashlight test.
  5. Argyll Robertson pupil (ARP) . Here the pupil is slightly small in size and reaction to near reflex is present but light reflex is absent, i.e., there is light near dissociation (to remember, the acronym ARP may stand for 'accommodation reflex present'). Both pupils are involved and dilate poorly with mydriatics. It is caused by a lesion (usually neurosyphilis) in the region of the tectum.
  6. The Adie's tonic pupil. In this condition reaction to light is absent and the near reflex is very slow and tonic. The affected pupil is larger (anisocoria). Its exact cause is not known. It is usually unilateral, associated with absent knee jerk and occurs more often in young women. Adie's pupil constricts with weak pilocarpine (0.125%) drops, while normal pupil does not.

Reference: Kanski clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, page no.780

questions.text: A 40 year old male patient presented to emergency with complaint of dizziness and palpitations.On examination Blood pressure was 80/60 mmHg.Urgent ECG was done which shows narrow complex tachycardia.What is the best management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Cardioversion is the treatment of choice in patients with narrow complex tachycardia who are hemodynamically unstable.

So in this patient, BP was 80/60 mmHg and in ECG narrow complex tachycardia is present. So the answer is Cardioversion.

Option A: IV Adenosine would be the answer if it was documented Narrow complex tachycardia with hemodynamically stable.

Option B: IV Verapamil is also used in hemodynamically stable patients.

Option C: IV Fluid has no role in any tachyarrhythmias and is bound to worsen the pulmonary edema that may develop.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1899

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with infertility and palpable pelvic mass. Her CA-125 level is 90 mIU/mL, diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
CA-125 is a non-specific tumor marker, elevated in both malignant and benign ovarian epithelial tumors.

The cut-off level for CA-125 is < 35 U/mL.

Elevated CA-125 levels can be seen in all options mentioned in the question.

Palpable mass may also be present in all four conditions.

The patient's age of 35 years favors endometrioma (endometriosis) the most.

Peak incidence of invasive ovarian cancer is at 56-60 years, and for borderline tumors, it is around 46 years.

Tuberculosis commonly affects patients in their twenties.

CA-125 has least significance in tuberculosis as it is neither used for diagnosis nor follow-up.

In young females, CA-125 > 200 IU/mL may indicate malignancy.

The most probable diagnosis based on age and infertility is endometrioma/endometriosis.

Reference: Novak Gynecology 14th edition page no 1466, 1146, 1147; Williams Gynecology, 1st edition, page no p 232, 210.

questions.text: Root value of Upper trunk of the brachial plexus is?
questions.solution:
Trunks of the brachial plexus:

  • Roots C5 and C6 join to form the upper trunk.
  • Root C7 forms the middle trunk.
  • Roots C8 and T1 join to form the lower trunk.
  • These lie in the neck between scalenus anterior and scalenus medius muscles, carrying axillary sheath from prevertebral fascia.

Reference: B.D.Chaurasia's Human Anatomy, 8th Edition, Volume - 1, Page No - 61

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with a history of Crohn's disease is experiencing diarrhea and abdominal cramping. A diagnostic test reveals that the patient's intestinal motility is increased. Select the correct neurotransmitter and match with its effect from the following.
questions.solution:
Serotonin stimulates peristalsis and increases intestinal motility. This can lead to diarrhea and abdominal cramping. In Crohn's disease, increased levels of serotonin are often found in inflamed intestinal tissue.

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page no 787-794

questions.text: A 2-year old child presented with a history of delayed walking and unsteady gait. History of redness of eyes and recurrent infections was also present. On examination, ataxia was observed. Serum IgA was decreased. On repeated presentation and further work up, defects in ATM gene were identified. Abnormality in which of the following mechanisms is involved in pathogenesis of the disease?
questions.solution:
Option C: This is a case of Ataxia Telangiectasia, caused by defects in homologous recombination factors. Other examples of diseases caused by the same mechanism are Bloom syndrome, Fanconi anemia, and familial breast cancers associated with BRCA mutations.

Ataxia telangiectasia is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by defects in ATM, a gene encoding a kinase that acts upstream of p53. This syndrome is characterised by neurodegeneration (particularly of the cerebellum, hence the ataxia), immunodeficiency, hypersensitivity to radiation (due to an inability to repair double-stranded DNA breaks), and predisposition to cancer, particularly certain forms of leukaemia and lymphoma. Somatic driver mutations in ATM also are common in certain types of lymphoid neoplasms.

Option A: HNPCC syndrome is caused by defects in DNA mismatch factors.

Option B: Subset of endometrial carcinomas and colon cancers are caused by defects in DNA polymerase.

Option D: Xeroderma pigmentosum occurs due to loss-of-function mutations in genes involved in nucleotide excision repair.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 314-315

questions.text: Which of the following anti-rheumatoid arthritis drug require liver function testing before starting of the treatment?
questions.solution:
Side effects of Methotrexate

Oral ulceration and GI upset are the major side effects of low dose methotrexate regimen.

With prolonged therapy, dose dependent progressive liver damage leading to cirrhosis occurs in some patients, while this is not seen with short courses used for cancer. Incidence of chest infection is increased.

Methotrexate is contraindicated in pregnancy, breast-feeding, liver disease, active infection, leucopenia and peptic ulcer.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no 228

questions.text: A patient with diabetic retinopathy presents with proliferative changes. Which of the following is the most effective treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
• Panretinal photocoagulation is the most effective treatment for proliferative diabetic retinopathy, which is a complication of diabetes that can lead to neovascularization and retinal detachment.
  • The other three options may be used in the management of diabetic retinopathy, but they are less effective than panretinal photocoagulation.

Reference: Kanski clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, page no 510

questions.text: A 50 year old man who had recently joined a gym collapsed on the treadmill. He was rushed to hospital where ECG shows presence of:
questions.solution:
• The ECG shows the patient has sinus rhythm, normal qrs axis.
  • Upsloping ST segment is seen V2-V5 and I and aVL.
  • ST depression seen in II, III, aVF leads.
  • This suggests Acute extensive anterior wall MI.
  • Brugada syndrome has ST elevation in V1-V3 and can present with sudden collapse during physical exertion but the collapse occurs due to Ventricular tachycardia. ECG strip however does not show any tachyarrhythmias.
  • Arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia shows presence of epsilon waves.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1829

questions.text: Rekha, 28-year-old nulliparous woman complains of severe menorrhagia and lower abdominal pain for 4 months. On examination there was a 14 weeks size uterus with fundal fibroid. The treatment of choice is:
questions.solution:
First, let us see whether we would like to go for medical management or surgical intervention.

The patient is presenting with:

  • Severe menorrhagia
  • Chronic lower abdomen pain

These indications are strong enough for surgical intervention.

Earlier size of fibroid >12 weeks was also an indication for surgery but nowadays it is not.

  • Now comes the question - whether myomectomy or hysterectomy should be done.
  • Indication of Myomectomy: Myomectomy is specifically indicated in an infertile woman or woman desirous of bearing child and wishing to retain her uterus.
  • Since, our patient, Sucheta is just 29 years and nulliparous-Myomectomy should be done.

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 15th edition, Page no 360.

choices.text: Occur in both muscle and liver
Excess of acetyl CoA stimulate it
Carbon skeleton of amino acid is involved

questions.text: False about gluconeogenesis is?
questions.solution:
• Gluconeogenesis occur in liver and kidney, not in the muscle
  • Gluconeogenesis prevent hypoglycemia in prolonged fasting
  • Excess Acetyl CoA is an allosteric activator of Pyruvate Carboxylase, a key enzyme of Gluconeogenesis
  • Carbon skeleton of gluconeogenic amino acid are involved in gluconeogenesis.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, Page no 187

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male patient presents with complain of swelling over the midaxillary region for the past 1 week. Patient has a history of diabetes mellitus for 10 years. The swelling was reddish tender and indurated with multiple pus points. Which of the following statements are true for the microbiological process happening inside that swelling?
1) tissue macrophages are the first line of defence against the infection 2) the first effect produced by the products of infection is the rapid enlargement of the tissue macrophages followed by the second effect in which the previously sessile macrophages break loose from their attachments and become mobile
3) second macrophage invasion into inflamed tissue is second line of defence
4) the monocytes are present abundantly in the blood and immediately get converted into macrophages during the second macrophage invasion process
5) macrophage can phagocytosis more number of bacteria, larger particles and even neutrophils and more necrotic tissue then the other phagocytic cells
6) increase production of granulocytes and monocytes by the bone marrow is third line of defence
questions.solution:
1) Tissue macrophages example histiocytes in the subcutaneous tissue, alveolar macrophages, microglia in the brain are the first line of defence against any infection

2) statement is true

3) invasion of neutrophils into the infected tissue is the second line of defence while the second macrophage invasion into the inflamed or infected tissue is the third line of defence

4) the monocytes are present in less number in blood and when they invade the tissue they take more than 8 hours to swell and increase their lysosome content and mature into macrophages

5) is true

6) increase production of granulocytes and monocytes by the bone marrow is the fourth line of defence which takes 3 to 4 days to reach the stage at which these cells leave the bone marrow

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 19th Edition, Page no 435, 436

questions.text: Inhibition of which of the following Biological mediator is the main mechanism of action of Sarilumab?
questions.solution:
• TNF-α blocking agents: Etanercept, adalimumab, infliximab, golimumab, and certolizumab block TNF-α action. They are given subcutaneously, except infliximab (given intravenously). These drugs are used in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and can cause activation of latent tuberculosis. Infliximab is also used in Crohn's disease, psoriatic arthritis, Wegener's granulomatosis, and sarcoidosis.
  • Co-stimulation inhibitors: Abatacept and belatacept inhibit co-stimulatory molecules (CD80 and CD86) on antigen-presenting cells, reducing T-cell activation. They are used in RA resistant to methotrexate and TNF-α inhibitors.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists: Tocilizumab and sarilumab target IL-6 receptors. Tocilizumab is approved for RA in combination with methotrexate and for cytokine release syndrome.
  • Rituximab: It depletes B-cells and is used for RA in combination with methotrexate.
  • Anakinra: It is an IL-1 receptor antagonist used for RA.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 13th edition, page no 662

choices.text: Surgical decompression of the seventh cranial nerve
Prednisone 60 mg daily for 5 days and then tapered over 5 days

questions.text: A 24-year-old with unilateral facial weakness, you diagnose a simple Bell's palsy without any other neurologic deficits. Laboratory studies including an erythrocyte sedimentation rate, Lyme titer, and angiotensin-converting enzyme level are normal. Chest x-ray is normal. Which of the following is the next most reasonable therapeutic step?
questions.solution:
• Symptomatic measures for Bell's palsy include:
    1. the use of paper tape to depress the upper eyelid during sleep and prevent corneal drying,
    2. artificial tears,
    3. massage of the weakened muscles.
  • A course of glucocorticoids, given as prednisone 60-80 mg daily during the first 5 days and then tapered over the next 5 days, modestly shortens the recovery period and improves the functional outcome.
  • Although large and well-controlled randomised trials found no added benefit of the antiviral agents valacyclovir (1000 mg daily for 5-7 days) or acyclovir (400 mg five times daily for 10 days) compared with glucocorticoids alone, some earlier data suggested that combination therapy with prednisone plus valacyclovir might be marginally better than prednisone alone, especially in patients with severe clinical presentations.
  • For patients with permanent paralysis from Bell's palsy, a number of cosmetic surgical procedures have been used to restore a relatively symmetric appearance to the face.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3440

questions.text: A 30 years old lady presented with creamy white vaginal discharge with fishy odour, drug of choice is:
questions.solution:
Creamy white discharge with fishy odour is characteristic of bacterial vaginosis (M/C cause Gardnerella). Drug of choice for management of bacterial vaginosis/ Gardnerella vaginitis is- Metronidazole: Dose - 500 mg oral metronidazole is given twice daily for 7 days

Alternatively, metronidazole gel (can be applied once daily for 5 days or clindamycin cream (2%) at bedtime for 5 days.

Note: Treatment of male sexual partner is not required in bacterial vaginosis.

In pregnancy:

  • Bacterial vaginosis is associated with preterm birth and premature rupture of membranes.
  • Treatment is reserved for symptomatic women who usually complain of fishy odor.
  • DOC - Metronidazole (oral) in the 2nd and the 3rd trimester.

Unfortunately, treatment does not reduce preterm birth and routine screening is not recommended.

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 15th edition, Page no 131; Williams Gynecology, 1st edition, page no 51.

questions.text: Baudelocque diameter is also known as:
questions.solution:
Clinical pelvimetry:

  • The interspinous diameter, between the outer borders of anterior superior iliac spines, measures 22-25 cm.
  • The intercristal diameter, the widest distance between the outer borders of the iliac crests, measures 25-28 cm.
  • The external conjugate or Baudelocque diameter, the distance between the tip of the spine of vertebra S5 and the upper border of the pubic symphysis, measures not less than 19 cm.
  • The intertuberous diameter, between the lowermost and innermost points on the two ischial tuberosities, measures 10 cm.
  • The anteroposterior diameter of the outlet measures about 13 cm.
  • The posterior sagittal diameter, from the midpoint of the intertuberous diameter to the tip of the coccyx, measures 8-9 cm.
  • The diagonal conjugate is the distance between midpoint of promontory and lower border of anterior surface of pubic symphysis. Normally, it is at least 11.5 cm. A rough estimate of the true conjugate is obtained by deducting 1.5 to 2 cm from the diagonal conjugate.
  • The interischial spinous diameter of 9 cm between the tips of the spines is difficult to assess digitally.

Reference: B.D.Chaurasia's Human Anatomy, 8th Edition, Volume - 2, Page No - 227, 228

choices.text: Hypovolemic shock; Plasma transfusion along with IV fluids administration
Diabetic Ketoacidosis; NS bolus and Insulin administration via 2 separate IV lines
Diabetic Nephropathy; Insulin administration along with Antidiabetic drugs

questions.text: A 57 years old male patient having persistent hyperglycemia since past 15 years reports to Emergency dept. On physical examination and checkup, he is found dehydrated and BP is 90/70 mmHg along with kussmaul's type of respiration. Urine examination reveals high concentration of electrolytes and is acidic in nature. What could be the probable diagnosis of the given case scenario and match with the appropriate management.
questions.solution:
• Diabetic ketoacidosis is caused by increased fatty acid metabolism and the accumulation of ketoacids (acetoacetate and β-hydroxybutyrate).
  • DKA usually occurs in insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus in association with cessation of insulin or an illness such as an infection, gastroenteritis, pancreatitis, or myocardial infarction, which increases insulin requirements temporarily and acutely.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition, Page no 318

questions.text: A 15-month-old child presented to paediatric OPD with ambiguous genitalia, on investigation his BP is 110/70 mm Hg, Serum K is 6.5 mEq/L, serum sodium is 115 mEq/L. He was later started on intravenous fluids. What is the most specific therapy will you add to this patient immediately?
questions.solution:
Normal serum K+ level is 3.5-5.0 mEq/L. Normal Na+ level is 136-152 mEq/L.

So, the patient in the question has hyperkalemia and hyponatremia. This together with ambiguous genitalia suggests the diagnosis of CAH (Congenital adrenal hyperplasia).

In CAH, there is deficiency of glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids

Hydrocortisone is the glucocorticoid with maximum mineralocorticoid activity,

so it is the preferred drug for treatment of this patient.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no314

questions.text: Below given pic can be used for all except:
questions.solution:
• Determination of meridian of optical iridectomy - in patients with corneal scar or lenticular opacity
  • To diagnose cases of cataract, by differentiating between coloured halos caused in Angle closure glaucoma and cataract by Fincham's test.

Slit passed across pupil

Halos break-Cataract

Halos remain intact-Angle closure glaucoma

  • Determine power and axis of cylinder - The slit aperture acts as an elongated 'pin-hole, only allowing light in the axis of the slit to enter the eye. Hence, when the slit lies in one principal axis of the astigmatic eye, the second line focus is eliminated and the blur of Sturm's conoid reduced thus allowing a clearer image to be formed.

Reference: Parson's Diseases of the Eye, 22nd Edition, Page no 397

choices.text: Immediately taper valproate and start lamotrigine
Continue valproate with monitoring of drug level

questions.text: A 29 year old, 4month pregnant primigravida has a history of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy. She has been regularly taking sodium valproate and now seeking an opinion for her antiepileptic regimen. What would you suggest?
questions.solution:
• The patient is in the second trimester of pregnancy. Organogenesis occurs in early pregnancy and damage may have already occurred.
  • The foetus may already be having a Neural tube defect and hence,there is no point to changing her treatment plan. Patients should also take folate (1-4 mg/d), because the antifolate effects of anticonvulsants are thought to play a role in the development of neural tube defects,
  • If patient presented when she was planning her pregnancy,the course of action would be to gradually reduce valproate dose and initiate lamotrigine.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3323

questions.text: Devikaben, 45 years old women present with history of poly-menorrhea for the last six months. The first line of management is:
questions.solution:
Progesterone therapy is commonly used to regulate menstrual cycles and manage conditions like menorrhagia (excessive or prolonged menstrual bleeding). By providing hormonal support and inducing a withdrawal bleeding, progesterone can help regulate the menstrual cycle and improve the symptoms of poly-menorrhea.

Other options like hysterectomy, dilation and curettage (D&C), and oral contraceptives may be considered in specific cases or after further evaluation if progesterone therapy does not provide sufficient relief. However, starting with progesterone therapy is often the initial approach to manage poly-menorrhea.

Reference: Jeffcoate's Principles of Gynaecology, 7th edition, Page no 610

questions.text:
Match each description with the correct nerve fibre.
1) Detect increase in muscle tension
2) Stimulation leads to contraction of the bulk of skeletal muscle
3) Muscle stretch leads to a direct increase in its firing rate
A) α-motor neurons
B) γ-motor neurons
C) Group Ia fibres
D) Group Ib fibres
questions.solution:
• The Golgi tendon organs are high threshold stretch receptors present in the tendons which are supplied by group Ib afferent fibres and detect muscle tension.The axons of alpha motor neurons innervate the extrafusal fibres of the skeletal muscles and are responsible for the contraction of muscles in the upper limbs, trunk and lower part of the body.
  • Group Ia fibres, also known as primary sensory endings, supplying central receptor portions of both nuclear bag as well as nuclear chain fibres are stimulated when the muscle spindle is stretched.
  • Gamma motor neurons innervate the intrafusal fibres of the muscle spindles and are responsible for maintenance of muscle tone.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Page no 95

choices.text: May be life saving in infant with aortic valve atresia

questions.text: An image of a congenital left to right shunt is shown below. Which of the following is not true regarding this defect?
questions.solution:
Option B: PDA is usually asymptomatic at birth, and a narrow PDA may have no effect on the child's growth and development.

Option A: PDA produces a characteristic, continuous, harsh 'machinery-like' murmur.

Option C: Isolated PDA should be closed as early in life as is feasible; therapy includes prostaglandin synthesis inhibitors and possibly percutaneous or surgical interventions.

Option D: In CHD with aortic valve or pulmonary valve atresia, a PDA may provide the entire systemic blood flow or pulmonary blood flow, respectively.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th edition, Page no 538

questions.text: A 16 year old type-1 diabetes mellitus patient was on Continuous subcutaneous insulin infusion. While on holiday with her family she become disoriented. On admission Na=126mEq/dl, Potassium=4.3mEq/dl, BUN=100mg/dl, bicarbonate is 10 mEq/dL and blood sugar is 600 mg%. All are required for management except?
questions.solution:
• A patient of Type 1 Diabetes mellitus is on CSII (Continuous subcutaneous insulin infusion).
  • Due to device malfunction the delivery of insulin was halted.
  • Since patients of Type 1 diabetes are ketosis prone, she has gone into Diabetic ketoacidosis. The low bicarbonate points to acidosis.
  • The patient's elevated blood sugar is drawing water into the intravascular compartment and hence volume expansion explains sodium deficit. However ,there is no need of hypertonic saline as correction of hyperglycemia by insulin shall suffice in managing hyponatremia.
  • Hypertonic saline is only given in acute onset hyponatremia with neurological features.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3116

questions.text: A 12-year-old young girl presents in the casualty with acute pain in the lower abdomen. She has history of cyclical pain for last 5 months and she has not attained her menarche yet. On local genital examination, a tense bulge in the region of hymen was seen. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this case is an imperforate hymen. Imperforate hymen is a congenital condition in which the hymen, a thin membrane that partially covers the opening of the vagina, does not have an opening, causing obstruction to menstrual blood flow. This condition is usually diagnosed during adolescence when menstrual periods start, and the blood accumulates behind the imperforate hymen, leading to cyclic lower abdominal pain. It may also present with a bulging bluish membrane at the vaginal opening on examination.

A young girl who has not attained menarche but has history of cyclical pain for last 6 months, presenting to casualty with acute abdomen and on examination a tense bulge in the region of hymen - clearly point towards 'Imperforate hymen' as the diagnosis.

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 15th edition, Page no 96-97

questions.text: Which of the spinal root involved in knee jerk?
questions.solution:
• Patellar tendon reflex or knee jerk (L3, L4).
  • The knee joint gets extended on tapping the ligamentum patellae.

Reference: B.D.Chaurasia's Human Anatomy, 8th Edition, Volume - 2, Page No - 62

questions.text: Which amino acid can act as buffer at neutral pH?
questions.solution:
• Amino acid which can protonate and deprotonate means those which can act as buffer.
  • Amino acid whose pKa = pH of the medium has maximum buffering capacity.
  • pKa of imidazole group of histidine is 6.5-7.4.
  • At pH = 7, Imidazole group of histidine can act as buffer.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, Page no 11, 12

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding metaplasia?
questions.solution:
Vitamin A (retinoic acid) deficiency can induce squamous metaplasia in the respiratory epithelium and in the cornea, the latter with highly deleterious effects on vision.

A direct link between transcription factor dysregulation and metaplasia is seen with vitamin A (retinoic acid) deficiency or excess, both of which may cause metaplasia. Retinoic acid regulates gene transcription directly through nuclear retinoid receptors, which can influence the differentiation of progenitors derived from tissue stem cells.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 61

questions.text: A 37 year old female patient prescribed risperidone for schizophrenia. Later she comes to the emergency room with an upward fixed gaze & bizarre muscle spasms. How do you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Acute muscular dystonias:

  • Bizarre muscle spasms, mostly involving linguo-facial muscles-grimacing, tongue thrusting, torticollis, locked jaw; occurs within a few hours of a single dose or at the most in the first week of therapy.
  • It is more common in children below 10 years and in girls, particularly after parenteral administration; overall incidence is 2%. It lasts for one to few hours and then resolves spontaneously.

One of the central anticholinergics, Promethazine or hydroxyzine injected i.m. clears the reaction within 10-15 min.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no 471

questions.text: Smoke stack pattern in FFA is seen in:
questions.solution:
CENTRAL SEROUS RETINOPATHY (CSR):

Central serous retinopathy is an idiopathic detachment of the neurosensory retina in the region of the macula due to the accumulation of serous fluid

More common in males aged between 20 and 40 years.

  • Risk factors: Stress, smoking and steroids.Seen in Type A personalities
  • Sudden onset decrease in vision associated with micropsia and metamorphopsia
  • Localised detachment of neurosensory retina at the posterior pole leading to acquired hypermetropia(effective shortening of the globe)
  • Fundus fluorescein angiography: The classical patterns are Smoke Stack Pattern or Mushroom/Umbrella pattern

Ink Blot Pattern" (Enlarging Dot Sign)

Treatment:

  • Wait and watch (as spontaneous resolution occurs in about 12 weeks)
  • Photocoagulation, anti-VEGF injections are options where resolution does not occur in three months.

Reference: Kanski clinical ophthalmology, 9th edition, page no 598

questions.text: A 50 year old male patient presents with unilateral painful opthalmoplegia. Imaging revealed an enlargement of cavernous sinus on the affected side.The likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• Cavernous sinus syndrome is a distinctive and frequently life-threatening disorder.
  • It often presents as orbital or facial pain; orbital swelling, chemosis due to occlusion of the ophthalmic veins; fever; oculomotor neuropathy affecting the third, fourth, and sixth cranial nerves; and trigeminal neuropathy affecting the ophthalmic (V1) and occasionally the maxillary (V2) divisions of the trigeminal nerve.
  • Cavernous sinus thrombosis, often secondary to infection from orbital cellulitis (frequently Staphylococcus aureus), a cutaneous source on the face, or sinusitis (especially with mucormycosis in diabetic patients), is the most frequent cause; other etiologies include aneurysm of the carotid artery, a carotid-cavernous fistula (orbital bruit may be present), meningioma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma, other tumours, or an idiopathic granulomatous disorder (Tolosa-Hunt syndrome).
  • The Tolosa-Hunt syndrome may be regarded as an extension of orbital pseudotumor through the superior orbital fissure into the cavernous sinus and causes enlargement of cavernous sinus.
  • The Tolosa-Hunt syndrome causes painful ophthalmoplegia, ptosis, headache, and cavernous sinus inflammation; biopsies and clinical follow-up may be needed to distinguish the Tolosa-Hunt syndrome from mucormycosis by the lack of progression of the former entity.
  • At the petrous apex, mastoiditis can produce deafness, pain, and ipsilateral abducens palsy is called Gradenigo's syndrome.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3444

questions.text: A 34-year-old mother of two children has been suffering from amenorrhea for the last 12 months. She has a history of failure of lactation following second delivery but remained asymptomatic thereafter. Skull X-ray shows empty sella, diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Empty Sella:

  • Congenital incompleteness of the sellar diaphragm.
  • Secondary to surgery/radiotherapy or infarction of pituitary tumour.
  • Secondary to infarction and necrosis of pituitary gland.

Now from the given causes: either pituitary tumour or Sheehan's syndrome can cause an empty sella on X-ray.

Pituitary tumours (micro/macroadenoma) are prolactin secreting tumours and hence, cause galactorrhea (not lactational failure) with amenorrhea and are ruled out.

So, the obvious answer by exclusion is Sheehan's Syndrome.

Sheehan's syndrome:

  • It is the syndrome which results from ischemic necrosis of most of the anterior pituitarydue to spasm in its arterioles occurring at the time of severe haemorrhage or shock, complicating childbirth.

Reference: Williams Gynecology, 1st edition, page no 374

choices.text: It is seen in areas of necrosis
Their deposition can be intracellular as well as extracellular
It is seen in advanced atheromas in atherosclerosis

questions.text: What is false regarding the type of calcification shown in the image?
questions.solution:
• Image shows dystrophic calcification.
  • Serum calcium is normal in dystrophic calcification.

OptionA: Dystrophic calcification is encountered in areas of necrosis, whether they are of coagulative, caseous, or liquefactive type, and in foci of enzymatic necrosis of fat.

Option D: Calcification is almost always present in the atheromas of advanced atherosclerosis. It also commonly develops in aging or damaged heart valves, further hampering their function.

Option C: Histologically, with the usual H&E stain, calcium salts have a basophilic, amorphous granular, sometimes clumped appearance. They can be intracellular, extracellular, or in both locations.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 65-66

choices.text: Drugs that must be sold by retail only when a prescription by RMP is produced
Drugs that shall be marketed under generic names only
Psychotropic drugs requiring special licence for manufacture and sale

questions.text: Based on 'Drugs and cosmetics act 1940' along with 'Drugs and cosmetic rules 1945' and its amendments, which of the following deals with Schedule X.
questions.solution:
• 'Drugs and cosmetics act 1940' along with 'Drugs and cosmetic rules 1945' and its amendments describe various schedule of drugs. Important schedules are:

Schedule Deals with

C and C1 -- Biological and special products

F and F1 -- Bacterial vaccines

G -- Drugs to be labelled with the word 'Caution'- It is dangerous to take this

preparation except under medical supervision

H -- Drugs that must be sold by retail only when a prescription by RMP is produced

M -- Good manufacturing practices (GMP)

P -- Expiry period of drug formulations

W -- Drugs that shall be marketed under generic names only

X -- Psychotropic drugs requiring special licence for manufacture and sale

Y -- Requirements and guidelines on clinical trials, import and manufacture of new drugs

Reference: Katzung Basic and Clinical Pharmacology, 14th Edition, Page no 1050, 1052

choices.text: Loss of anterior horn cells in the spinal cord

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents with weakness in his right lower limb about 6 months ago in the form of tripping over his toes and dragging his foot. He also gets frequent cramps in the mornings. The weakness is progressing to involve both legs now. On examination, you note tongue fasciculations. DTR are 3+ at the knees and ankles. Strength is 4 - at the extensors and flexors of Lower limb. Hand grip strength is also 4+. Which of the following is the suspected pathologic lesion(s)?
questions.solution:
• This patient is presenting with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), a common motor neuron disease.
  • This progressive disease has no curative treatment at this time, and it leads to disability and death due to respiratory failure within 3-5 years after diagnosis.
  • The pathologic hallmark of ALS is loss or death of both upper and lower motor neurons.
  • The upper motor neuron loss can be demonstrated by degeneration of the corticospinal tracts typically originating in layer five of the motor cortex and descending downward via the pyramidal tract to synapse with the lower motor neurons both directly and indirectly via interneurons.
  • The lower motor neuron disease is manifested by death of anterior horn cells in the spinal cord and brainstem, which can lead to bulbar symptoms. Clinically, this leads to the classic findings of both upper and lower motor neuron disease in ALS.
  • The most common presenting symptom in ALS is asymmetric weakness of insidious onset that is most prominent in the lower extremities. Muscle wasting and atrophy may be prominent. A detailed history can elicit cramping with volitional movement, such as stretching, which is most common in the early morning hours.
  • Fasciculations may be identified. When the muscles of the hands are involved, extensor weakness is more common than flexor weakness.
  • Bulbar symptoms include difficulty with chewing, swallowing, and movements of the face and tongue.
  • Upper motor neuron symptoms may lead to spasticity with increased deep tendon reflexes. However, even in late stages of the disease, sensory and cognitive functions are preserved.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3410

questions.text: Appropriate material for antenatal diagnosis of genetic disorders includes all of the following except:
questions.solution:
The appropriate material for antenatal diagnosis of genetic disorders includes all of the following except maternal urine.

Maternal urine can be used to screen for some genetic disorders, such as Down syndrome. However, it is not as accurate as other methods, such as chorionic villus sampling or amniocentesis.

Reference: Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, page no 389

choices.text: Motility examination of the cardinal positions of the gaze.

questions.text: What is the best way to distinguish a restrictive motility disorder from a paretic disorder after a blowout fracture?
questions.solution:
• Alternate prism cover tests, Goldmann single binocular fields, and a careful motility examination are all good ways to identify or quantify ocular misalignment, but will not distinguish paralytic from restrictive cases.
  • Forced-duction testing is the best clinical tool to distinguish these two entities and should be done several days after the injury.
  • Edema and/or a hematoma may cause initial forced ductions to appear positive and give a false impression that entrapment exists.
  • After topical anesthesia is obtained with tetracaine, the episcleral tissues at the inferior limbus are grasped with toothed forceps. The eye is then rotated in the desired direction, and comparisons can be made with the uninjured side.
  • In cases of paralytic strabismus, the forced ductions are free, unlike cases of restrictive strabismus.

Reference: Kanski Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, Page no 116

questions.text: Investigation of choice in a 55-year-old post-menopausal woman who has presented with postmenopausal bleeding:
questions.solution:
In a woman with postmenopausal bleeding chances of endometrial carcinoma are very high. Therefore, such a patient should be evaluated so as to rule out endometrial carcinoma. Hence fractional curettage should be done.

Investigations for endometrial carcinoma:

  1. Endometrial aspiration biopsy: This is the first step in evaluating a patient with abnormal uterine bleeding. It is a simple and painless procedure that can be done in the doctor's office.
  2. Dilatation and fractional curettage: This is a more invasive procedure that is done under anesthesia. It allows the doctor to remove more tissue from the uterus, which can help to confirm the diagnosis of endometrial carcinoma.
  3. Hysteroscopy and biopsy: This is a procedure that allows the doctor to look inside the uterus with a small camera. A biopsy can be taken at the same time.
  4. Transvaginal ultrasound: This can be used to measure the thickness of the endometrium and to look for polyps or other abnormalities.
  5. Pap smear: This is not a reliable test for diagnosing endometrial carcinoma, but it can be used to rule out other conditions.

Reference: William's Gynaecology, 3rd Edition, Page no 185, 708

questions.text: A 35 year old female named rameela presented to gynaecology department with unilateral breast cancer, later she was put on tamoxifen therapy for the cancer. Which of the following dreaded adverse effect is often associated with the use of tamoxifen?
questions.solution:
Tamoxifen is a SERM that acts as antagonist at estrogen receptors in the breast. It decreases the risk of contralateral breast cancer and is approved for primary prevention of breast cancer in women at high risk.

Adverse effects of Tamoxifen include:

  • Hot flashes
  • Vaginal discharge or bleeding
  • Menstrual irregularities
  • Thromboembolic events (rare)
  • Endometrial hyperplasia/Carcinoma
  • Cataract
  • Hepatotoxicity

Reference: Goodman and Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 13th edition, page no 812

questions.text: A 30 year old male patient complaints of palpitations and examination shows irregularly irregular pulse, Pulse deficit=16/min and BP 118/74mmHg. Which of the following will be found in this patient in JVP waves?
questions.solution:
• Irregularly irregular pulse with pulse deficit >10/min indicates atrial fibrillation. Since atria are twitching then a wave in JVP would be absent.
  • Option b is seen in complete heart block, Junctional Tachycardia and Ventricular Tachycardia.
  • Option c is seen in cardiac tamponade
  • Option d is seen with tricuspid regurgitation and Constrictive pericarditis.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1904

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a fibroid uterus develops acute pain in abdomen with low grade fever and mild leucocytosis at 28 weeks. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The answer is quite obvious but let's see how other options can be ruled out.

Red degeneration of fibroid: also called as Carneous degeneration.

  • It is seen mostly during mid pregnancy(but can occur at other times, as well as in nonpregnant females also)
  • It is an aseptic condition
  • The myoma suddenly becomes acutely painful, enlarged and tender
  • Patient presents with: Acute abdominal pain,Vomiting,Malaise,Slight fever
  • Lab investigations: Moderate leukocytosis, Raised ESR

Pathological changes in the tumour:

  • Fibroid becomes soft, necrotic or homogenous especially in its centre
  • It is stained Salmon pink, or red (due to diffusion of blood pigments from the thrombosed vessels)
  • It has fishy odour(due to secondary infection with coliform organisms)
  • Histologically: There is evidence of thrombosis in some vessels
  • Pathogenesis: There is subacute necrosis of the myoma caused by an interference in blood supply (aseptic infarction).

Diagnosis is by ultrasound.

Differential diagnosis:

  • Appendicitis, Twisted ovarian cyst, Pyelitisand Accidental haemorrhage
  • So amongst the above options - Red degeneration is the correct answer.

Management:

  • Conservative management
  • Patient is advised rest
  • Analgesics are given to relieve the pain

The acute symptoms subside in 3-10 days and pregnancy proceeds uneventfully.

Reference: Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition, page no 314.

questions.text: A 28-yr old woman presents with pulmonary embolism. She has a history of recurrent miscarriages. Her laboratory studies show normal prothrombin time with raised partial thromboplastin time. Lab results also showed a positive test for syphilis. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Option C: The clinical manifestations of APS are varied; they include recurrent thromboses, repeated miscarriages, cardiac valve vegetations, and thrombocytopenia. Depending on the vascular bed involved, the clinical presentations can include pulmonary embolism (following lower extremity venous thrombosis), pulmonary hypertension (from recurrent subclinical pulmonary emboli), valvular heart disease, stroke, bowel infarction, or renovascular hypertension.

Antiphospholipid antibodies frequently result in a false-positive serologic test for syphilis because the antigen in the standard assay is embedded in cardiolipin, which cross reacts with phospholipids of Treponema pallidum.

Option A: Individuals with such mutations have a significantly increased frequency of venous thrombosis in the setting of other acquired risk factors (e.g., pregnancy or prolonged bed rest).

Option B: Deficiencies of factors V, VII, VIII, IX, and X are associated with moderate to severe bleeding disorders.

Option D: HIT syndrome is a serious, potentially life-threatening disorder that occurs following the administration of unfractionated heparin. It results from the formation of antibodies that recognize complexes of heparin and PF4 on the surface of platelets, as well as complexes of heparin-like molecules and PF4-like proteins on endothelial cells.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 127-128

questions.text: Correct combination of Urine odour in various metabolic disorder:
questions.solution:
Peculiar odours in different Aminoacidurias

  • Hawkinsinuria:- Swimming pool
  • Maple syrup urine disease:- Maple Syrup
  • Hypermethioninemia:- Boiled Cabbage
  • Multiple carboxylase deficiency:- Tomcat urine
  • Phenylketonuria:- Mousy Body
  • Trimethylaminuria:- Rotting fish
  • Tyrosinemia:- Rotten cabbage, rancid butter
  • Alkaptonuria:- Black urine

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, Page no 304

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient having hip replacement surgery, complaining of chest pain, difficulty in breathing and coughing after 2 days of surgery. Patient's ECG shows Right ventricular hypertrophy and tricuspid regurgitation. Blood reports show a high level of d- dimer. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given clinical scenario points towards Pulmonary embolism.

  • Pulmonary emboli (annual incidence, ~1 per 1000) can produce dyspnea and chest discomfort that is sudden in onset.
  • The chest discomfort associated with pulmonary embolism may result from involvement of the pleural surface of the lung adjacent to a resultant pulmonary infarction, distention of the pulmonary artery or possibly, right ventricular wall stress and/or sub endocardial ischemia related to acute pulmonary hypertension.

Reference: Harrisons Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition, Page no 76

questions.text: A patient was scheduled for surgery. As a part of pre-anaesthetic medication, he was administered glycopyrrolate. What is the rationale of giving glycopyrrolate before anaesthesia?
questions.solution:
Preanesthetic medication refers to the use of drugs before anaesthesia to make it safe and less unpleasant.

  • When inhalation anaesthetic agents are given, they inhibit the ciliary function resulting in accumulation of secretions in the respiratory pathway. Therefore anticholinergic drugs like atropine or glycopyrrolate are used as preanesthetic medication for their antisecretory action.
  • Glycopyrrolate is twice as potent and longer acting quaternary antimuscarinic which does not produce central effects. Antisecretory Action is more marked than atropine and tachycardia is less marked. It acts rapidly when given IV and is the preferred antimuscarinic in anaesthetic practice.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no 413, 414

questions.text: A 26 year old male patient had increased frequency of stool 15-16 episodes and decreased urine output for 2 days on ABGA metabolic acidosis and hyperkalemia of K=5.9mEql/dl. All of the following are the ECG features of Hyperkalemia except?
questions.solution:
Hyperkalemia can cause various cardiac arrhythmias, including bradycardia, ventricular rhythms, tachycardia, and fibrillation.

Mild hyperkalemia affects T-wave morphology, while severe cases result in widened QRS and loss of P waves.

A Brugada pattern on the ECG, absent P waves, and marked QRS widening can indicate hyperkalemia.

ECG changes progress from tall T waves to loss of P waves, widened QRS, and potentially a sine wave pattern.

Prompt monitoring and intervention are essential to manage hyperkalemia and prevent life-threatening arrhythmias.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 353

questions.text: 26 yrs old female patient with a history of epilepsy 10 days ago wants to take OC pills. Contraceptive to be avoided in epilepsy:
questions.solution:
Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) can interact with anti-epileptic drugs (AEDs), and this can increase the risk of seizures. For this reason, OCPs are not recommended for women with epilepsy.

Condoms, IUCDs, and Mirena are all safe for women with epilepsy.

Oral contraceptives (OCs) are not recommended for women with epilepsy because they can increase the risk of seizures. This is because OCs can interact with anti-epileptic drugs (AEDs), and this can increase the levels of AEDs in the blood. High levels of AEDs can increase the risk of seizures.

Reference: Clinical Gynecologic Endocrinology and Infertility by Leon speroff, 8th edition, page 1026

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of tabes dorsalis?
questions.solution:
Tabes dorsalis is the result of damage to the sensory axons in the dorsal roots. This causes impaired joint position sense and ataxia (locomotor ataxia); loss of pain sensation, leading to skin and joint damage (Charcot joints); other sensory disturbances, particularly the characteristic 'lightning pains'; and absence of deep tendon reflexes.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 1264

questions.text: A male with short stature presented with weakness of muscle, recurrent infection. ECHO results indicated enlarged heart and reduced ejection fraction. He was diagnosed with Barth syndrome. Which of the following lipid component is decreased in this disorder?
questions.solution:
• Phosphatidic acid is a precursor of phosphatidylglycerol, which in turn gives rise to cardiolipin.
  • This phospholipid is found only in mitochondria and is essential for the mitochondrial function.
  • Decreased cardiolipin levels or alterations in its structure or metabolism cause mitochondrial dysfunction in aging and in pathological conditions including heart failure, hypothyroidism, and Barth syndrome (cardioskeletal myopathy).

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition. Page no 217

questions.text: Primigravida with full term pregnancy, complains of faintness on lying down and she feels well when turning to the side or sitting position. This is due to:
questions.solution:
SUPINE HYPOTENSION SYNDROME (POSTURAL HYPOTENSION): During late pregnancy, the gravid uterus produces a compression effect on the inferior vena cava when the patient is in supine position.

In 90% cases this, however, results in opening up of the collateral circulation by means of paravertebral and azygos veins.

In some cases (10%), when the collateral circulation fails to open up, the venous return of the heart may be seriously curtailed.

This results in production of hypotension, tachycardia and syncope called supine hypotensive syndrome.

The normal blood pressure is quickly restored by turning the patient to lateral position.

That is why pregnant females are advised to lie in lateral positions best being left lateral.

Reference: Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 7th edition, page no 406

questions.text: What is the management of Heparin induced thrombocytopenia?
questions.solution:
• In Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), one of the major concerns is the development of thrombosis (blood clots). Therefore, evaluating for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and other thrombotic events is an essential part of the management. This involves clinical assessment and possibly imaging studies to identify any thrombotic complications.
  • Stopping all forms of heparin (unfractionated heparin and LMWH) and initiating alternative anticoagulation therapy are also crucial aspects of the management, as mentioned in the previous response. Additionally, platelet transfusion is not recommended in HIT as it can exacerbate thrombotic complications.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 931

questions.text: What is true about hereditary angioneurotic edema?
questions.solution:
Option C: Mast cell-independent, IgE-independent. These forms of urticaria are triggered by local factors that increase vascular permeability. One form is initiated by exposure to chemicals or drugs, such as aspirin, that inhibits cyclooxygenase and arachidonic acid production. The precise mechanism of aspirin-induced urticaria is unknown. A second form is hereditary angioneurotic edema caused by an inherited deficiency of C1 inhibitor that results in excessive activation of the early components of the complement system and production of vasoactive mediators.

Option A: Mast cell-dependent, immunoglobulin E (IgE)-dependent. Urticaria of this type follows exposure to many different antigens (pollens, foods, drugs, insect venom) and is an example of a localized immediate hypersensitivity (type I) reaction triggered by the binding of antigen to IgE antibodies that are attached to mast cells through Fc receptors.

Option B: Mast cell-dependent, IgE-independent. This subset results from substances that directly incite the degranulation of mast cells, such as opiates, certain antibiotics, and radiographic contrast media.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 1154

questions.text: A lady has ovarian mass, X-ray pelvis shows a radio- opaque shadow. The probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
An ovarian mass with radio opaque shadow on X-ray points towards the dermoid cyst as the diagnosis.

Causes of Pelvic Calcification are:

  1. Fibroids: popcorn type
  2. Dermoid cyst: it is the commonest ovarian mass to calcify
  3. Other ovarian masses: cystadenoma / carcinoma, fibromas
  4. Pseudomyxoma peritonei
  5. Fallopian tube calcification (rare): suggest TB
  6. Uterine i.e. endometrial calcification from chronic endometritis

Reference: Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition, Page no 202-211

questions.text:
Choose the correct answers for the given statements.
1. Have Highest Transmembrane Electrical Gradient
2. Has Highest Equilibrium Potential
3. Ion having Closest RMP to Muscle
4. Ion having Closest RMP to Nerve
questions.solution:
• Hair Cell in Cochlea Has ECF Similar to ICF having High K+ Levels. It has a Highest Transmembrane Electrical Gradient of -150mv.
  • K+ has Closest to Nerve Potential.
  • Cl- has Closest to Muscle Potential.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology 25th Edition. Page no 85-90, 199-205

questions.text: Which of the following has highest electrophoretic mobility and least lipid content:
questions.solution:
HDL

  • Alpha lipoprotein
  • Least Diameter
  • Maximum Electrophoretic Mobility
  • Maximum Protein Content
  • Least lipid content
  • Carry Cholesterol from peripheral tissues to liver and other steroidogenic tissues
  • This is called Reverse Cholesterol transport
  • This makes HDL Cholesterol 'the good cholesterol'
  • The major role of HDL is to acts as the repository for apo C and apo E required for the metabolism of VLDL and Chylomicron.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, Page no 254

questions.text: Which of the following conditions causes conjugated bilirubinemia?
questions.solution:
(A) Viral hepatitis can cause liver inflammation and impairment of liver function. It can lead to an increase in both unconjugated and conjugated bilirubin, causing conjugated bilirubinemia.

(B) Hemolytic anemia: This condition involves increased destruction of red blood cells, leading to an increase in unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin. It does not cause conjugated bilirubinemia.

(C) Physiologic jaundice of the newborn: In newborns, a common temporary condition called physiologic jaundice can occur due to the immature liver's inability to effectively process bilirubin. This condition typically leads to an increase in unconjugated bilirubin and does not cause conjugated bilirubinemia.

(D) Breast milk jaundice: Breast milk jaundice is a type of jaundice that can occur in some breastfed infants. It is caused by certain substances in breast milk that interfere with bilirubin metabolism. Similar to physiologic jaundice, it primarily leads to an increase in unconjugated bilirubin and does not cause conjugated bilirubinemia.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th edition, Page no 853

questions.text: A female has history of 6 weeks amenorrhea, USG shows empty sac, serum β-hCG 6500 IU/L. What would be next management?
questions.solution:
The patient is presenting with an empty gestational sac on ultrasound and high levels of β-hCG. This is suggestive of an ectopic pregnancy. Ectopic pregnancy is a condition in which the fertilized egg implants outside of the uterus. It is a serious condition that can be life-threatening.

The first line of treatment for ectopic pregnancy is medical management with methotrexate. Methotrexate is a medication that can be used to terminate the pregnancy.

If medical management is not successful, then surgical management may be necessary. Surgical management involves removing the ectopic pregnancy, either through laparoscopy or laparotomy.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 7th edition, Page no 182, 183

questions.text: Functions of Superior Rectus muscles are all except:
questions.solution:
The superior rectus muscle is one of the extraocular muscles responsible for eye movements.

Its primary functions include:

A) Elevation: It helps in upward movement of the eye, i.e., looking upward.

B) Intorsion: It aids in inward rotation of the eye.

C) Adduction: It assists in inward movement of the eye, i.e., looking inward toward the nose.

Option D (Abduction) is incorrect because the superior rectus muscle does not play a role in outward movement of the eye, i.e., looking away from the nose. Outward eye movement is primarily controlled by the lateral rectus muscle.

Reference: Kanski clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, Page no.703

questions.text:
After 120 days of circulation in blood, the RBC matures and such matured RBC are less active and more and more fragile. Which of the following match is correct regarding the source of small amount of ATP in such mature RBC and function of that source respectively.
(X) Mitochondria
(Y) Cytoplasmic enzymes
(1) Decreases the pliability of cell membrane.
(2) Prevents oxidation of proteins in red cells
(3) Maintain the iron in cell's Hb in ferrous state rather than ferric form
(4) Performs oxidative phosphorylation to generate ATP
questions.solution:
• Mature red cells do not have nucleus, mitochondria, and endoplasmic reticulum. But they do have cytoplasmic enzymes and they are capable of metabolizing glucose and forming small amounts of ATP. These enzymes also (a) maintain the pliability of cell membrane (b) prevents the oxidation of proteins in red cells (c) keep iron of cell's Hb in ferrous form rather than ferric form.
  • Incorrect option: A - Mitochondria is absent in mature RBC
  • Incorrect option B - These enzymes also maintain the pliability of cell membrane.
  • Incorrect option D - Cytoplasmic enzymes prevents the oxidation of protiens in cells.

Correct Option: C, because cytoplasmic enzymes are present in mature RBC and as explained their function is correctly matched

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 19th Edition, Page no 445

questions.text: All of the followings structures forms boundaries of calot's triangle, except:
questions.solution:
Calot's triangle:

  • Triangular space formed by
    • Cystic duct
    • Common hepatic duct
    • Segments V of right hemiliver (inferior surface)
  • This space contains cystic artery, cystic lymph node and autonomic fibres reaching the gallbladder.

Reference: B.D.Chaurasia's Human Anatomy, 8th Edition, Volume -2, Page No - 341

questions.text: A 38 year old smoker construction worker present with low back pain.The pain is worse on standing and improves with sitting .Reflexes are diminished in right lower limb with absence of sensation in both lower limbs.What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history points to neurogenic claudication.

  • Pain on standing and improvement with sitting. Focal deficit of some diminished reflexes can be explained by the same.
  • Vascular claudication develops on walking and not on standing. Hence option b is ruled out.
  • In a construction worker, spinal cord trauma can occur while lifting bricks and etc. which results in spinal canal stenosis.
  • Tethered cord syndrome is a developmental disorder of the lower spinal cord and nerve roots that rarely presents in adulthood as low back pain accompanied by a progressive lower spinal cord and/or nerve root syndrome. It presents as cauda equina syndrome leading to urinary complaints and saddle anaesthesia.
  • Vertebral metastasis is unlikely at this age.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3446

questions.text: In a pregnant woman with heart disease, all of the following are to be done except:
questions.solution:
Methergine is a medication that is used to control bleeding after childbirth. However, it is contraindicated in patients with heart disease, as it can cause narrowing of the blood vessels and make the heart work harder.

The other options are all appropriate for the management of a pregnant woman with heart disease.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 7th edition, Page no 278

questions.text: A 31 year old female with Graves disease was on medication for hyperthyroidism throughout the pregnancy. She delivered a child with congenital anomaly named `aplasia cutis congenita'. Which of the following drug is most likely implicated for this teratogenic effect is?
questions.solution:
All Antithyroid drugs (carbimazole, methimazole, propylthiouracil) if taken during pregnancy can cause Fetal hypothyroidism, congenital goiter, scalp defects (aplasia cutis congenita).

Use of antithyroid drugs in pregnancy may result in:

- Fetal hypothyroidism

- Aplasia cutis

- Scalp or patchy hair defect

- Choanal atresia

- Esophageal atresia

- Tracheo-esophageal fistula

- Minor facial anomalies

- Hypoplastic or absent phalanges

- Psychomotor delay

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 13th edition, page no 797

questions.text: Which of the following syndromes is likely to be transmitted by the inheritance pattern shown in this pedigree chart?
questions.solution:
Option D: Image shows pedigree of Leber hereditary optic neuropathy, a disorder caused by mutation in mitochondrial DNA. All progeny of an affected male (shaded squares) are normal, but all children, male and female, of the affected female (shaded circles) manifest disease to a variable degree.

Option A: Angelman syndrome may occur by deletion of maternal gene on chromosome 15, uniparental disomy of chromosome 15, or defective imprinting.

Option B: Osteogenesis imperfecta is an Autosomal dominant disorder.

Option C: Fragile X Syndrome results from a trinucleotide expansion mutation in the familial mental retardation 1 (FMR1) gene.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 178

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of following case?
questions.solution:
Brown-Sequard syndrome:

  • This is caused due to hemisection of the spinal cord.
  • Below the level of lesion:
    • Ipsilateral upper motor neuron paralysis caused by pyramidal tract damage.
    • Ipsilateral loss of conscious proprioceptive sensations caused due to damage to posterior white column.
    • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature and touch caused due to damage to lateral spinothalamic and anterior spinothalamic tracts.
  • At the level of lesion:
    • Ipsilateral lower motor neuron paralysis caused due to damage to ventral nerve roots.
    • Ipsilateral anaesthesia over the skin of the segment due to injury to the ventral nerve roots.
  • Above the level:
    • Ipsilateral hyperaesthesia above the level of lesion due to irritation of dorsal nerve roots.

Reference: B.D.Chaurasia's Human Anatomy, 8th Edition, Volume -4, Page No - 50, 51

questions.text: Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by measurement of ?
questions.solution:
• Riboflavin released by the catabolism of enzymes is rapidly incorporated into newly synthesised enzymes.
  • Deficiency is characterised by cheilosis, desquamation and inflammation of the tongue, and a seborrheic dermatitis.
  • Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro
  • Decreased RBC Transketolase activity, Thiamin is a cofactor of Transketolase.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, Page no 556

questions.text: A 30 year old female patient present to you with pancytopenia under investigations.On Lower limb doppler there is Deep vein thrombosis.You suspect the diagnosis of Paroxysmal Nocturnal hemoglobinuria. What is the gold standard test for diagnosis of PNH?
questions.solution:
• The gold standard today is flow cytometry, which can be carried out on granulocytes as well as on red cells and has a very high sensitivity
  • Flow cytometry is used to detect CD59(MIRL), a glycoprotein and CD55(DAF)in regulation of complement action.
  • Absence or reduced expression of both CD59 and CD55 on PNH RBC is diagnostic.
  • The HAM test establishes the diagnosis of PNH, demonstrating a characteristic abnormality of PNH red blood cells by acidified fresh normal serum.Hence is a PNH patient's red blood cells lysed by normal serum at room temperature and at 370C compared with normal red cells.
  • Heated serum at 56oC inactivates complement and prevents hemolysis in PNH cells.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 789

questions.text: 32 weeks pregnant women presents with mild uterine contraction and on examination her vitals are stable and placenta previa type III is present. Best management is:
questions.solution:
The patient is presenting with mild uterine contractions and placenta previa type III. Placenta previa is a condition in which the placenta implants in the lower part of the uterus, near or over the cervix. This can cause bleeding during pregnancy or childbirth.

The best management for this patient is to put her on bed rest and give her Nifedipine, a tocolytic medication that can help to stop the uterine contractions. Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid that can be given to help to mature the fetal lungs in case of preterm delivery.

Reference: Fernando Arias textbook of OBG, 3rd edition, page no 341

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for Intravenous Regional Anaesthesia?
questions.solution:
• Intravenous regional anaesthesia (IVRA) is indicated for any procedure on the arm below the elbow or leg below the knee that will be completed within 40-60 minutes.
  • An intravenous cannula is inserted in a distal vein in the limb scheduled for surgery. The tourniquet is then applied to the upper arm or thigh. The local anaesthetic solution is then slowly injected into the cannula.
  • The drug of choice for IVRA is prilocaine as it is the least toxic local anaesthetic and has the largest therapeutic index.
  • If prilocaine is not available, lignocaine is an acceptable alternative. It is essential that plain and not adrenaline-containing solutions are used.
  • Bupivacaine should never be employed as it is too toxic, particularly to the myocardium.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 13th edition, page no 412

questions.text: In case of strangulation of the femoral hernia, surgeon cuts which of the folowing ligaments?
questions.solution:
• In cases of strangulation of a femoral hernia, the surgeon has to enlarge the femoral ring.
  • This is possible only by cutting the lacunar ligament; which forms the medial boundary of the ring.
  • Normally, this can be done without danger.
  • Occasionally, however, an abnormal obturator artery may lie along the edge of the lacunar ligament; and cutting it may cause alarming haemorrhage.

Reference: B.D.Chaurasia's Human Anatomy, 8th Edition, Volume - 2, Page No-54

questions.text: A 29 year old female patient had a pathological fracture of clavicle, ribs and Xray shows Subperiosteal resorption of 2nd and 3rd metatarsal and phalanges. On Blood investigation Hypocalcemia and hypophosphatemia seen. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The distinctive bone manifestation of hyperparathyroidism is osteitis fibrosa cystica, which occurred in 10-25% of patients in series reported 50 years ago.
  • Histologically, the pathognomonic features are an increase in the giant multinucleated osteoclasts in scalloped areas on the surface of the bone (Howship's lacunae) and a replacement of the normal cellular and marrow elements by fibrous tissue.
  • X-ray changes include resorption of the phalangeal tufts and replacement of the usually sharp cortical outline of the bone in the digits by an irregular outline (subperiosteal resorption).
  • In recent years, osteitis fibrosa cystica is very rare in primary hyperparathyroidism, probably due to the earlier detection of the disease.
  • In osteomalacia Calcium and Phosphorus both are low due to Vit.D deficiency.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3175

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with abnormal cervical cytology on PAP smear suggestive of CIN (III). The next best step in management is:
questions.solution:
The patient in the question has CIN (III) on pap smear. PAP smear is only a screening procedure and is not diagnostic, hence for confirming the diagnosis, we will have to do colposcopy.

A patient with CIN III on pap smear should be evaluated with colposcopy. If CIN III is confirmed on colposcopy, the preferred treatment is LEEP. LEEP can be done in a single step or in two steps. In young females, it is recommended to do colposcopy first to confirm CIN III, and then do LEEP. In older females, LEEP can be done directly during colposcopy without confirming CIN III histologically.

Cryosurgery is not recommended for the treatment of CIN 3 because it has a higher rate of disease persistence and does not allow for histological examination to exclude occult invasive cancer.

Hysterectomy is no longer the preferred treatment for CIN 3 in all age groups. LEEP is now the procedure of choice for managing CIN 2/CIN 3 in all age groups.

Reference: Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, page 366.

questions.text: A 85 year old female patient presented with seizure followed by altered sensorium since 1 day. She is a known case of HTN for 20 years on triple drug combinations. On blood investigation she had Sodium of 110 mEq/L. Patient was treated with 3% NaCl and now patient became unconscious and quadriparesis and her MRI brain done shows below. Identify the below image?
questions.solution:
OSMOTIC DEMYELINATION SYNDROME (CENTRAL PONTINE MYELINOLYSIS)

  • This disorder often presents in a devastating fashion as quadriplegia and pseudobulbar palsy, although less severe presentations may occur.
  • Predisposing factors include severe underlying medical illness or nutritional deficiency; most cases are associated with rapid correction of hyponatremia or with hyperosmolar states, and clinical symptoms are usually identified a few days after sodium correction.
  • Previously termed central pontine myelinolysis, the more accurate term osmotic demyelination syndrome is now preferred. The pathology consists of demyelination without inflammation in the base of the pons, with relative sparing of axons and nerve cells.
  • MRI is useful in establishing the diagnosis and may also identify partial forms that present as confusion, dysarthria, and/or disturbances of conjugate gaze without quadriplegia.
  • Occasional cases present with lesions outside of the brainstem. Therapy for the restoration of severe hyponatremia should aim for gradual correction, i.e., by ≤8 mmol/L (8 meq/L) within 24 h and 15 mmol/L (15 meq/L) within 48 h.

Reference: Harrison's principle of medicine, 21st edition, Page 2273

questions.text: A 15-year old boy presented with a sudden onset of severe headache and seizures.
