MRI brain showed a nodule obstructing the cerebral aqueduct, multiple subependymal nodules and small cortical foci. Patient had history of learning difficulties. On general examination, leathery-appearing (Shagreen patches) and hypopigmented (Ash-leaf macules) were noted, scattered all over the body. Biopsy of the nodule showed subependymal giant cell astrocytoma. Which chromosomal abnormality is likely to be detected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from tuberous sclerosis.

  • It is characterized by the development of hamartomas and benign neoplasms involving the brain and other tissues; the most frequent clinical manifestations are seizures, autism, and intellectual disability. Hamartomas within the CNS take the form of cortical tubers and subependymal nodules; subependymal giant cell astrocytomas are benign neoplasms that appear to develop from the hamartomatous nodules in the same location. Cortical tubers are often epileptogenic, and surgical resection can be beneficial when medical management of the seizures fails.
  • Cutaneous lesions include angiofibromas, localised leathery thickenings (shagreen patches), hypopigmented areas (ash-leaf patches), and subungual fibromas.

Option A: One tuberous sclerosis gene (TSC1) is found on chromosome 9q34 and encodes a protein known as hamartin; the more commonly mutated gene (TSC2) is on 16p13.3 and encodes tuberin. These two proteins form a complex that inhibits the kinase mTOR. mTOR controls cell size, and the tumour cells associated with TSC, particularly the subependymal giant cell astrocytomas, are remarkable for having voluminous cytoplasm.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 1302

questions.text: Which of the following mitochondrial (Cytochrome) enzyme involved in the metabolism of Theophylline?
questions.solution:
CYP2D6 This is the next most important CYP isoform which metabolizes nearly 20% drugs including tricyclic antidepressants, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, many neuroleptics, antiarrhythmics, codeine, debrisoquine, metoprolol.

CYP2C8/9 Important in the biotransformation of commonly used drugs including phenytoin, carbamazepine, warfarin which are narrow safety margin drugs.

CYP2C19 Metabolizes frequently used drugs including omeprazole, lansoprazole, phenytoin, diazepam. Omeprazole and fluconazole are its inhibitors.

CYP1A1/2 Though this subfamily participates in the metabolism of only few drugs like theophylline, caffeine, paracetamol, carbamazepine, it is more important for activation of procarcinogens.

CYP2E1 It catalyses oxidation of alcohol, halothane, and formation of minor metabolites of few drugs, notably the hepatotoxic N-acetyl benzoquinoneimine from paracetamol; chronic alcoholism induces this isoenzyme.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no 29

questions.text: A patient presents with a sudden onset of unilateral eye pain, headache, and blurred vision. Examination reveals conjunctival injection, corneal edema, and a fixed and dilated pupil. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Acute angle-closure glaucoma. The clinical presentation of sudden onset eye pain, headache, and blurred vision with conjunctival injection, corneal edema, and a fixed and dilated pupil is consistent with acute angle-closure glaucoma.

Reference: Kanski clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, page no 372

questions.text: During PPH, we have to ligate the arteries in step wise manner. Among them, Uterine artery is a branch of:
questions.solution:
• The uterine artery is a branch of the internal iliac artery.
  • It supplies blood to the uterus and cervix.
  • The uterine artery crosses the ureter near the cervix.
  • This is the most common site of ureteric injury during hysterectomy.
  • The branches of the uterine artery to the uterus are the arcuate artery, radial artery, basal artery, and spiral artery.

Reference: JB Sharma textbook of Gynecology, 2nd edition, page no 10

questions.text: Which of the following spike proteins on Coronavirus facilitate fusion of viral membrane to cell membrane?
questions.solution:
The coronavirus has a set of surface, crown-shaped proteins called spike proteins (S proteins). These are homotrimers consisting of proteins S1 and S2. Cryoelectron microscopy has suggested that, subsequent to binding of the virus to the ACE2 receptor, the S1 subunit dissociates from the receptor, inducing activation of the S2 protein that facilitates the fusion of the viral membrane to the cell membrane, allowing for viral transport into the cell.

Reference: Henry's clinical diagnosis and management by laboratory methods, 24th edition, Page no 309

questions.text: 12 years old child fall from the tree, he clutched one of the branch of tree during he fell. After few weeks his parents observed loss of sensation on medial side of forearm and claw hand. What is the site of injury in this case?
questions.solution:
Klumpke's Paralysis:

  • Site of injury: Lower trunk of the brachial plexus.
  • Cause of injury: Undue abduction of the arm, as in clutching something with the hands after a fall from a height, or sometimes in birth injury.
  • Nerve roots involved: Mainly T1 and partly C8.
  • Muscles paralysed: Intrinsic muscles of the hand (T1) and Ulnar flexors of the wrist and fingers (C8).
  • Deformity and position of the hand:
    • Claw hand due to the unopposed action of the long flexors and extensors of the fingers.
    • In a claw hand, there is hyperextension at the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion at the interphalangeal joints.
  • Disability:
    • Complete claw hand
    • Cutaneous anaesthesia and analgesia in a narrow zone along the ulnar border of the forearm and hand.
    • Horner's syndrome: If T1 is injured proximal to white ramus communicans to first thoracic sympathetic ganglion, there is ptosis, miosis, anhydrosis, enophthalmos, and loss of ciliospinal reflex. This is because of injury to sympathetic fibres to the head and neck that leave the spinal cord through nerve T1.

Reference: B.D.Chaurasia's Human Anatomy, 8th Edition, Volume - 1, Page No - 63

questions.text: Paracrine signaling affects?
questions.solution:
In paracrine signaling, only cells in the immediate vicinity are affected. To accomplish this, there can be only minimal diffusion, after which the secreted signal is rapidly degraded, taken up by other cells, or trapped in the ECM.

Option B: In endocrine signaling, a mediator is released into the bloodstream and acts on target cells at a distance.

Option C: Autocrine signaling occurs when molecules secreted by a cell affect that same cell. This can be a means to entrain groups of cells undergoing synchronous differentiation during development, or it can be used to amplify (positive feedback) or dampen (negative feedback) a particular response

Option D: In synaptic signaling, activated neurons secrete neurotransmitters at specialized cell junctions (i.e., synapses) onto target cells.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 17

questions.text: A 30 year old male given blood transfusion in the O.T. following which he develops tachycardia, hypotension BP=70/40mmHg and hematuria within 10 minutes of starting the transfusion. The most probable cause?
questions.solution: Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 894

questions.text: Kamala, a 48-years-old lady underwent hysterectomy. On the seventh day, she developed fever, burning micturition and continuous urinary dribbling. She can also pass urine voluntarily. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
• Urinary fistulas are abnormal connections between the urinary tract and other organs or tissues, often resulting from surgery, childbirth, or injury.
  • Symptoms of urinary fistulas, such as continuous dribbling of urine after hysterectomy, usually appears within a few days or weeks of the injury, but in some cases, they may take several weeks or months to manifest.
  • Urethral fistulas, though less common, can occur due to urethral damage during childbirth.
  • It is essential to differentiate urinary fistulas from other conditions causing urinary incontinence, such as stress incontinence and urge incontinence, based on the patient's history and symptoms.
  • In this particular patient, the development of urinary incontinence after hysterectomy suggests a urinary fistula, with the timing of symptoms supporting this diagnosis.

Reference: Jeffcoate's Principles of Gynaecology, 7th edition, Page no 263, 265

questions.text: An 18-year-old comes to you for the first time after moving from a remote area with limited medical care. He has a history of multiple severe bacterial infections and albinism. A representative peripheral blood smear is shown below. What diagnosis is most consistent with this history and blood smear?
questions.solution:
• The blood smear in Figure demonstrates large granules in neutrophils consistent with the Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (CHS).
  • CHS is a rare disease with autosomal recessive inheritance due to defects in the lysosomal transport protein LYST, encoded by the gene CHS1 at 1q42. This protein is required for normal packaging and disbursement of granules.
  • Neutrophils (and all cells containing lysosomes) from patients with CHS characteristically have large granules, making it a systemic disease.
  • Patients with CHS have nystagmus, partial oculocutaneous albinism, and an increased number of infections resulting from many bacterial agents. Some CHS patients develop an 'accelerated phase' in childhood with a hemophagocytic syndrome and an aggressive lymphoma requiring bone marrow transplantation.
  • CHS neutrophils and monocytes have impaired chemotaxis and abnormal rates of microbial killing due to slow rates of fusion of the lysosomal granules with phagosomes. Natural killer (NK) cell function is also impaired.
  • CHS patients may develop a severe disabling peripheral neuropathy in adulthood.
  • In the Pelger-Hüet anomaly, a benign disorder, the majority of granulocytes are bilobed. The nucleus frequently has a spectacle-like, or 'pince-nez,' configuration.
  • Kostmann syndrome (neutrophil count <100/μL), is near complete absence of neutrophils and neutrophil precursors, which is often fatal due to mutations in the anti apoptosis gene HAX-1. The smear in acute leukaemia contains a uniform population of primitive myeloblasts with immature chromatin, nucleoli in some cells, and primary cytoplasmic granules.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, page no. 447

questions.text: Cobblestone appearance of the Conjunctiva is seen in:
questions.solution:
Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis

Vernal keratoconjunctivitis also known as spring catarrh is type 1 hypersensitivity reaction commonly seen in boys between age 5 and 15 years of age.

Symptoms: Itching associated with ropy discharge >Signs

Conjunctival features:

  • Flat topped papillae are seen on the upper tarsal conjunctiva. The typical appearance is called cobblestone appearance.
  • In the limbal variety, there is hypertrophy of the superior limbal conjunctiva. This gives rise to raised white nodules close to the upper limbus called Horner-Trantas spots

Corneal features:

  • Superficial punctate keratitis
  • Shield ulcer
  • Curved white line close to the upper limbus called pseudogerontoxon.

Treatment

Acute episode: The following drugs are given topically:

  • Antihistamines
  • Steroids
  • Cyclosporine

Prophylaxis:

The following drugs are given topically:

  • Sodium cromoglycate
  • Ketotifen
  • Olopatadine
  • Bepotastine

Reference: Kanski clinical ophthalmology, 9th edition, page no 181

questions.text: Which is the best technique used to measure the viral load of HIV virus?
questions.solution:
Option C: Real-time PCR is most often used to monitor the frequency of cancer cells bearing characteristic genetic lesions in the blood or in tissues (e.g., the level of BCR-ABL fusion gene sequences in patients with CML), or the infectious load of certain viruses (e.g., HIV, Epstein-Barr virus).

Option A & B: NGS is more sensitive than Sanger sequencing, as it can reliably identify the presence of mutations in only a small percentage of the individual sequencing reads. This situation is encountered frequently in cancers, either because the mutation in question is only present in a small fraction of tumor cells or because the tumor cells are heavily contaminated with genetically normal stromal cells.

Option D: It can be used when the trinucleotide expansion is so large that it cannot be amplified by convention PCR.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 181-182

questions.text: A case of Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia belongs to high risk group, if disease develops after:
questions.solution:
Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) is a rare cancer that develops from the placenta. It is most commonly caused by a hydatidiform mole, which is a benign tumor of the placenta.

GTN is considered to be high risk if it develops after a hydatidiform mole. This is because women who have had a hydatidiform mole are more likely to develop GTN again.

Reference: Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, page no 402

choices.text: Bioavailability is enhanced with Vitamin C
The proportion of iron absorption is reduce as haemoglobin improves
The reticulocyte count should begin to increase in 1 weeks and peak in 2 weeks-This suggest good response to treatment
The treatment should be discontinued immediately once haemoglobin normalises to prevent side effects of iron

questions.text: All of the following are the characteristic features of treatment of iron deficiency anaemia with oral iron supplements except?
questions.solution:
• The response to iron therapy varies, depending on the EPO stimulus and the rate of absorption.
  • Typically, the reticulocyte count should begin to increase within 4-7 days after initiation of therapy and peak at 1-1½ weeks.
  • The absence of a response may be due to poor absorption, noncompliance (which is common), or a confounding diagnosis.
  • A useful test in the clinic to determine the patient's ability to absorb iron is the iron tolerance test.
  • Two iron tablets are given to the patient on an empty stomach, and the serum iron is measured serially over the subsequent 2-3 h. Normal absorption will result in an increase in the serum iron of at least 100 μg/dL. If iron deficiency persists despite adequate treatment, it may be necessary to switch to parenteral iron therapy.
  • The goal of therapy in individuals with iron-deficiency anaemia is not only to repair the anaemia, but also to provide stores of at least 0.5-1 g of iron. Sustained treatment for a period of 6-12 months after correction of the anaemia will be necessary to achieve this.
  • A normal individual without iron deficiency absorbs 5-10% of this iron, or about 0.5-1 mg daily. Iron absorption is increased in response to low iron stores or increased iron requirements.
  • In an iron deficient individual ,about 50-100 mg of iron can be incorporated into haemoglobin daily, and about 25% of oral iron given as a ferrous salt can be absorbed.
  • Therefore 200-400 mg of elemental iron should be given daily to correct iron deficiency most rapidly
  • However, as the haemoglobin level rises, EPO stimulation decreases, and the amount of iron absorbed is reduced.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 752

questions.text: Match the following with regard to predominant role of molecules in leukocyte migration.
questions.solution:
Different molecules play predominant roles in different steps of this process: Selectins, in rolling; Chemokines (usually displayed bound to proteoglycans), in activating the neutrophils to increase avidity of integrins; integrins, in firm adhesion; and CD31 (PECAM-1), in transmigration.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 77

choices.text: Both hydrothorax and ascites must be present

questions.text: 48 years old female known case of ovarian tumor came to emergency room with ascites and hydrothorax. True about that is:
questions.solution:
• Meigs' syndrome is a rare condition characterized by ascites and right-sided hydrothorax in association with a benign ovarian tumor.
  • The pathophysiology of Meigs' syndrome is not fully understood, but it is thought to be caused by the release of substances from the tumor that stimulate the production of fluid in the peritoneum and pleural space.
  • The syndrome typically resolves spontaneously after removal of the tumor.
  • Pseudo-Meig's syndrome is a similar condition that can occur in association with other benign or malignant ovarian tumors.

Reference: Comprehensive Gynaecology by Arthus L Herbst, 2nd edition, page no 533

questions.text: All of the following are the causes of the hypersecretion of the prolactin hormone from the anterior pituitary gland except?
questions.solution:
• Oestrogen induces transient functional changes in lactotrophs, increasing PRL production.
  • PRL's predominant hypothalamic control is inhibitory, mediated by dopamine. This accounts for spontaneous PRL hypersecretion after pituitary stalk section due to head trauma or skull base mass lesions.
  • Risperidone, a D2 blocker, can lead to hyperprolactinemia.
  • Thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) can elicit PRL release within 15-30 minutes after intravenous injection, but its physiologic relevance for PRL regulation is unclear.
  • Serum PRL levels can transiently rise after activities such as exercise, meals, sexual intercourse, surgery, anesthesia, chest wall injury, acute myocardial infarction, and acute stress.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2892

questions.text: A 68-yr old man with a history of chronic alcohol and tobacco abuse complains of persistent dysphagia as well as odynophagia. He has also lost significant weight. On examination of peripheral smear, microcytic hypochromic picture is seen along with presence of many elliptocytes. On upper GI endoscopy, a 3 cm ulcerative mass is noted in the mid-esophagus, partially occluding the lumen. Image from biopsy of this lesion is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Risk factors for SCC oesophagus include alcohol and tobacco use, poverty, caustic esophageal injury, achalasia, Plummer-Vinson syndrome, diets that are deficient in fruits or vegetables, and frequent consumption of very hot beverages.
  • Patients typically have dysphagia, odynophagia (pain on swallowing), or obstruction at presentation and may have unknowingly adjusted to progressive esophageal obstruction by altering their diet from solid to liquid foods. Weight loss and debilitation result from both impaired nutrition and tumour cachexia. Symptoms of iron deficiency are often present.
  • Image shows squamous cell carcinoma composed of nests of malignant cells that partially recapitulate the organisation of squamous epithelium.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th edition, Page no 763-764

questions.text: A 60 year old male patient is known case of uncontrolled DM-II on oral hypoglycemic agent. Patient presented to us with Bilateral pedal edema. BP was 146/86mmHg. We want to see for Diabetic Nephropathy. What is the earliest finding we find?
questions.solution:
• Diabetic kidney disease refers to albuminuria and reduced GFR (<60 mL/min per 1.73 m2). Once there is marked albuminuria and a reduction in GFR, the pathologic changes are likely irreversible.
  • The nephropathy that develops in type 2 DM differs from that of type 1 DM in that albuminuria may be present when type 2 DM is diagnosed, reflecting its long asymptomatic period, and hypertension more often contributes to albuminuria and reduced GFR.
  • Albuminuria in type 2 DM may be secondary to factors unrelated to DM, such as hypertension, congestive heart failure (CHF), prostate disease, or infection.
  • As part of comprehensive diabetes care, albuminuria should be detected at an early stage when effective therapies can be instituted.
  • Assessment should include a spot urinary albumin-to-creatinine ratio and an estimated GFR because some individuals with type 1 or type 2 DM have a decline in GFR without albuminuria.
  • Routine urinalysis does not detect low levels of albumin excretion.
  • Screening for albuminuria should begin 5 years after the onset of type 1 DM and at the time of type 2 DM diagnosis.
  • Option A is ruled out, as glomerular hyperperfusion and renal hypertrophy occur in the first years after the onset of DM and are associated with an increase in the estimated glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3110-3112

choices.text: Reversion to the original position immediately by external version

questions.text: On external cephalic version, fetal bradycardia occurred. The next course of action is:
questions.solution:
External cephalic version:

Is done to bring favourable cephalic pole in the lower pole of uterus.

Indications:

  • Breech presentation
  • Transverse lie

Procedure:

  • The manoeuver is carried out after 35 weeks under the effect of Terbutaline 0.25 mg s.c. or Isoxsuprine 50-100 mg IV. Ultrasound examination is done to confirm the diagnosis and adequacy of amniotic fluid volume. A reactive NST should precede the manoeuver. Then ECV is attempted followed by a repeat NST after the procedure.
  • A reactive NST should be obtained after completing the procedure. There may be undue bradycardia due to head compression which is expected to settle down by 10 minutes. If however, fetal bradycardia persists, the possibility of cord entaglement should be kept in mind and in such cases reversion is done.
  • If version is successful the patient is observed for 30 minutes - To allow for the fetal heart rate to settle down to normal. If even after reversion, fetal distress persists-cesarean should be done.

Reference: Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 7th edition, page no 583

questions.text: A 30-yr old man and his wife have primary infertility. He also has a chronic history of sinus and respiratory tract infections. On chest X-ray, right-sided heart and aorta are observed. Gross appearance of his lung would be as shown in the image below. Mutation in which of the following proteins is likely?
questions.solution:
Image shows bronchiectasis in a patient with cystic fibrosis, who underwent lung transplantation. Cut surface of lung shows markedly distended peripheral bronchi filled with mucopurulent secretions.

Clinical history and investigations are suggestive of Kartagener syndrome (primary ciliary dyskinesia with situs inversus as well as bronchiectasis). Mutations in dynein, leading to defects in ciliary motor proteins is implicated.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th edition, Page no 687

questions.text: A 42 year old female patient had a palpable solitary nodule seen in the thyroid gland on examination and it is associated with cervical lymph node enlargement on same side. We do Needle biopsy from the nodule shows amyloid in stroma of lesion. What is likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• MTC is common in MEN 2A and MEN 2B.
  • Represents 5-10% of thyroid carcinomas, with 20% having family history.
  • Presents as neck mass, sometimes with pressure or dysphagia.
  • Diagnosis based on elevated calcitonin (>90 pg/mL).
  • Ultrasonography confirms and shows amyloid in stroma.
  • Radionucleotide scans reveal "cold" nodules.
  • Radiography shows dense calcification in thyroid and lymph nodes.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2953

choices.text: E6 stimulates expression of telomerase reverse transcriptase
E7 inactivates CDK inhibitors p21 and p27

questions.text: Which of the following is true about oncogenic activities of E6 and E7 proteins in HPV carcinogenesis?
questions.solution:
Oncogenic activities of E6:

The E6 protein binds to and mediates the degradation of p53 and stimulates the expression of telomerase reverse transcriptase (TERT), the catalytic subunit of telomerase, which you will recall contributes to the immortalization of cells. E6 from high-risk HPV types has a higher affinity for p53 than E6 from low-risk HPV types, a distinction that likely accounts for the difference in cancer risk.

Oncogenic activities of E7:

The E7 protein has effects that complement those of E6, all of which are centred on speeding cells through the G1/S cell cycle checkpoint. It binds to the RB protein and displaces the E2F transcription factors that are normally sequestered by RB, promoting progression through the cell cycle. As with E6 proteins and p53, E7 proteins from high-risk HPV types have a higher affinity for RB than do E7 proteins from low-risk HPV types. E7 also inactivates the CDK inhibitors p21 and p27. Finally, E7 proteins from high-risk HPVs (types 16, 18, and 31) also bind and presumably activate cyclins A and E.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 324-325

questions.text: A 38 year old woman approaches a physician for contraceptive advice. On examination, there were two symmetrical ulcers on the vulva, which were well-defined with a firm base. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Painless well-defined ulcers with firm base should raise the suspicion of chancre.

Chancre is the primary lesion of primary syphilis.

  • It is most commonly found on the labium majus, labium minus, fourchette, clitoris, urethral orifice or cervix but can be found anywhere on the lower genital tract.
  • In 10% cases more than one primary lesion is present.
  • The first manifestation is a small papule which breaks to form an ulcer.
  • Ulcer is firm, painless with raised edges and granulomatous base.
  • In fact any sort of discrete relatively painless ulceration on the vulva may be primary syphilitic lesion.
  • Inguinal glands enlarge when the primary lesion is on the vulva or lower vagina.
  • Lymph nodes are hard, shotty, painless, and do not suppurate.

Reference: Williams Gynecology, 1st edition, page no 58

questions.text: A 35 year old female patient comes with the altered sensorium. Her sodium level is 129 mEq/dL. She was euvolemic. Her urinary sodium was 25 and serum osmolality 268. All of the following are cause of euvolemic hyponatremia except?
questions.solution:
Euvolemic hyponatremia is a condition in which the sodium level in the blood is low, but the total body water is normal. In this scenario, the patient is euvolemic, meaning there is a normal fluid balance in the body. The given laboratory values indicate SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion) as the likely cause of hyponatremia.

The possible causes of euvolemic hyponatremia in this case are:

A. Glucocorticoid deficiency (Addison's disease): Glucocorticoid deficiency can lead to impaired water excretion by the kidneys and, therefore, dilutional hyponatremia.

B. Hypothyroidism: Hypothyroidism can lead to impaired water excretion, similar to glucocorticoid deficiency, resulting in euvolemic hyponatremia.

D. SIADH: SIADH is characterized by excessive release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH), leading to increased water reabsorption in the kidneys and dilution of sodium in the blood.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2925, 2924, 723

questions.text: A male patient presents after trauma with following injury and fracture of metatarsal bone. What is the Anderson Gustillo classification?
questions.solution:
Image shows extensive soft tissue damage with fracture of metatarsal bones but there is adequate coverage of periosteum present so it is classified as gustilo Anderson IIIA GRADE.

The patient has a large wound (>10 cm), extensive soft tissue injury, and a vascular injury requiring repair. This would classify the fracture as a Type IIIC open fracture.

Type I fractures have a small wound (<1 cm) and minimal soft tissue injury.

Type II fractures have a larger wound (1-10 cm) and moderate soft tissue injury.

Type IIIA fractures have a large wound (>10 cm) and extensive soft tissue injury, but no vascular injury.

Reference: Apley's System of Orthopaedics, 9th edition, page no 706

questions.text: A 13 year male child presented with complaints of fever and malaise associated with skin rash which appeared on hands followed by thighs and trunk. Rash gives the appearance of dew drop on rose petals. Name the characteristic skin lesion seen in the given condition?
questions.solution:
• Chickenpox is a highly contagious disease caused by the varicella-zoster virus.
  • The virus is spread through respiratory droplets or direct contact with fluid from the rash.
  • The incubation period (time from exposure to onset of symptoms) is 10-21 days.
  • The characteristic rash of chickenpox is a centrifugal rash, which means it starts on the chest and back and spreads to the rest of the body.
  • The rash is made up of small, itchy blisters that eventually crust over and fall off.
  • Other symptoms of chickenpox include fever, headache, cough, and sore throat.
  • Chickenpox is usually a mild illness, but it can be serious in infants, young children, and adults.
  • There is no specific treatment for chickenpox, but over-the-counter medications can help relieve symptoms.

Reference: IADVL textbook of dermatology, 4th edition, page 176

questions.text: A full term child was delivered by vaginal delivery. He did not cry soon after birth and bag and mask ventilation was given for 1 min after which the child had a weak cry. He was shifted to NICU where the child had worsening respiration. CXR was done as follows. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The CXR is very diagnostic of Pneumothorax. The sharp margin of air trapped on the left side with shifting of mediastinum on the right is suggestive of pneumothorax.
  • Aggressive bag and mask ventilation is known to cause pneumothorax.
  • HMD is a complication of preterm babies.
  • Congenital pneumonia does not present at birth. It slowly progresses over the first week. Also, there might be a history of some infection in the mother in the perinatal period.
  • TTN has sunburst appearance on X ray or signs of fluid collection in the interlobular spaces.

Reference: Cloherty and Stark's manual of newborn care, SA edition, page no 504

choices.text: Rape by the husband upon his wife during separation

questions.text: A magistrate inquest would not be required in which of the following cases?
questions.solution:
An act of Rape by the husband upon his wife during separation does not require a magistrate inquest. It is punishable under section 376B and is a cognizable and bailable offence.

Magistrate inquest (176 Cr.P.C) are done in the following cases:

1) Death in police custody, or while under police interrogation, or death due to police firing.

2) Death in prison, reformatories, Borstal school, psychiatric hospitals.

3) Dowry deaths

4) Exhumation

5) Rape is alleged to have been committed on a woman in the custody of the police or in any other custody authorised by the court.

6) In any case of death, a Magistrate may conduct an inquest, instead of or in addition to the police inquest.

Reference: The essentials of forensic medicine and toxicology by Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, 33rd edition, Page no 7

questions.text: Food poisoning in canned food is caused by
questions.solution:
The most common food associated with botulism are home preserved foods such as home canned vegetables, smoked or pickled fish, homemade cheese and similar low acid food.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 204, 253, 254, 293, 314

choices.text: Cyclically occurring episodes of mania and depression over 2 years
Cyclically occurring episodes of hypomania and subsyndromal depression over 2 years

questions.text: What is a Cyclothymic disorder?
questions.solution:
Cyclothymic disorder is a mood disorder that is characterized by alternating periods of hypomania and subsyndromal depression. Hypomania is a milder form of mania, and subsyndromal depression is a milder form of major depressive disorder.

The symptoms of cyclothymic disorder must last for at least 2 years, and there must be no periods of normal mood in between episodes. The symptoms must also cause significant impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page no 732-733

questions.text: Cleft lip is formed due to incomplete fusion between?
questions.solution:
Fusion of the processes takes place from anterior to posterior. Partial or complete failure of fusion results in abnormalities which range from a bifid uvula to clefts of varying severity. Failure of fusion between a maxillary process and the corresponding premaxilla causes a cleft lip. Failure of the maxillary and lateral processes to fuse produces a facial cleft with an open nasolacrimal furrow. Nonfusion between the palatine processes and nasal septum results in a cleft palate.

Reference: Scott-Brown's Otolaryngology: Head and Neck Surgery, 7th edition, volume 2, Page no 1320

choices.text: This extends beyond the boundaries of the original incision or wound
They are more common in areas of increased tension, wounds crossing tension lines, deep dermal burns and wounds left to heal by secondary intention (longer than 3 weeks).
The aetiology is unknown but genetic predisposition is implicated.
They often occur as a result of relatively minor trauma and mainly in those with darker skin pigmentation

questions.text: All are true about the conditions seen in this photograph except
questions.solution:
Hypertrophic scars do not extend beyond the boundary of the original incision or wound and eventually regress. They are more common in areas of increased tension, wounds crossing tension lines, deep dermal burns and wounds left to heal by secondary intention (longer than 3 weeks).

Keloid scars extend beyond the boundaries of the original incision or wound, do not spontaneously regress and are difcult to treat. The aetiology is unknown but genetic predisposition is implicated. They often occur as a result of relatively minor trauma and mainly in those with darker skin pigmentation.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 28

questions.text: You have given a supraclavicular block in a patient for an upper limb surgery, following which patient complaints of difficulty in breathing. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Although all these complications are possible with a supraclavicular block, most common complication is ipsilateral phrenic nerve palsy.

Nearly half of patients undergoing supraclavicular block will experience ipsilateral phrenic nerve palsy, although ultrasound guidance may decrease this incidence by allowing use of minimal local anesthetic volume.

Complications & side-effects of supraclavicular block :

  • Hemidiaphragmatic paresis - due to phrenic nerve palsy
  • Pneumothorax - highest among brachial plexus block
  • Horners syndrome - from block of the stellate ganglion
  • Hoarseness - due to recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy and/or cervical sympathetic block

Reference: Morgan and Mikhail's clinical anaesthesiology, 6th edition, page no 1010

choices.text: Prevalence is defined as the number of TB cases (all forms) at a given point in time.
Mortality from TB is defined as the number of deaths caused by TB, including those of patients with HIV-TB co-infection
Prevalence of infection is the percentage of individuals who show a positive reaction to the standard tuberculin test
None of the above; all the three are true statements

questions.text: Regarding tuberculosis, all of the following are true except:
questions.solution:
Mortality from TB is defined as the number of deaths caused by TB in HIV-negative people, according to the latest revision of the International Classification of Diseases (ICD-10). TB deaths among HIV-positive people are classified as HIV deaths in ICD-10. For this reason, estimates of deaths from TB in HIV-positive people are presented separately from those in HIV-negative people.

Prevalence is defined as the number of TB cases {all forms) at a given point in time. It is the best available practical index to estimate the case load in a community. The age-specific prevalence of patients is considered the most relevant index (option A).

Prevalence of infection is the percentage of individuals who show a positive reaction to the standard tuberculin test. When the test is done in defined age-groups, it yields age-specific prevalence which is a far superior indicator than the mere percentage of positive reactors in the total population. Prevalence represents a cumulative experience of a population to recent and remote infection with Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, page no 191

questions.text: Identify the B structure in this lower motor neuron?
questions.solution:
Alpha motor neurons innervate the extrafusal muscle fibers of the motor unit. They are responsible for voluntary muscle contraction.

Gamma motor neurons innervate the intrafusal muscle fibers of the muscle spindle. They are responsible for maintaining muscle tone and stretch reflexes.

Muscle stretch (tendon) reflex is a reflex that occurs when a muscle is stretched. It is responsible for maintaining muscle tone and preventing injury.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 166

questions.text: An 83-year-old man has a painful mass of the great toe. Radiographs and a biopsy specimen are seen below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Gouty arthritis, pseudogout, and infection can all present with inflammatory arthritis and periarticular erosions. Strongly negative birefringent crystals are seen in gout. The histologic image shows elongated 'needle-like' crystals of gout. Epidermal inclusion cysts are rarely painful and usually have a history of localised penetrating trauma.

Reference: Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th Edition, Page no 87,105

questions.text: A forest worker got a thorn prick which later developed with linear lesions and lymphatic spread. What will be the correct diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Sporothrix Schenckii is dimorphic fungus. It is natuarally found in soil, hay, sphagnum moss and plants. It usually affects farmers, gardeners and agricultural workers. It affects skin and subcutaneous tissue. It is also known as rose thorn or rose gardener's disease. In cutaneous form, it forms nodular lesions or bumps in the skin at the point of entry and also along lymph nodes and vessels. Lesion starts as a painless nodule and ranges in colour from pink to purple.

If untreated lesions become larger and look similar to a boil and more lesions will appear until a chronic ulcer develops. It occurs in the fingers, hands and arm.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 18th Edition, Page no 1665

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest risk for metabolic syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Risk for metabolic syndrome is highest for 2nd generation antipsychotics.
  • Clozapine and Olanzapine have the highest risk for metabolic syndrome.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page no 631, 632

questions.text: A congenitally deaf child on radiological evaluation of cochlea and brain with MRI/CT scan has been found to having normal cochlea with absence of eighth nerve on both sides. What is the best method of hearing rehabilitation in this case?
questions.solution:
This child has absence of VIII nerve bilaterally. So Auditory Brainstem Implant (ABI) surgery must be done.

ABI stimulate the cochlear nuclear complex in the brainstem directly by placing the implant in the lateral recess of the fourth ventricle.

Indications of ABI include -

  • Neurofibroma type 2 - Bilateral vestibular schwannoma
  • Congenital aplasia of VIII nerve
  • Cochlear aplasia (Michel Aplasia)

The prerequisite for cochlear implant surgery is presence of normal VIII nerve.

Reference - Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page - 147

choices.text: In chronic cases, a mass in the right iliac fossa may be an amoeboma but caecal cancer must be excluded by colonoscopy and biopsy
Serological tests are highly sensitive and specifc outside endemic areas
Medical treatment is very effective and should be the first choice in the elective situation, with surgery being reserved for complications
Pigtail catheter drainage may be considered in those patients who are not responding to intravenous metronidazole in the first 12 hours to improve antibiotic penetration

questions.text: A 24 yrs old male patient presented to opd with complains of incidious onset of pain in right upper abdomen and right shoulder tip , hiccoughs and a non productive cough, anorexia , fever ,night sweat and weight loss . Patient has past history of bloody diarrhoea and travel to africa.His ultrasound of abdomen was done. All are true about this condition except
questions.solution:
This is the case of amoebic liver abscess.

Medical treatment is very effective and should be the first choice in the elective situation, with surgery being reserved for complications. Metronidazole and tinidazole are the effective drugs. After treatment with metronidazole and tinidazole, diloxanide furoate, a luminal amoebicide that is not effective against hepatic infestation, is used for 10 days to destroy any intestinal amoebae.

Aspiration is carried out when imminent rupture of an abscess is expected, especially when involving the left lobe. Pigtail catheter drainage may be considered in those patients who are not responding to intravenous metronidazole in the first 48-72 hours to improve antibiotic penetration. If there is evidence of secondary infection, appropriate drug treatment is added

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 68

questions.text: Cis Atracurium is a potent isomerism of Atracurium. All of the following is true regarding its properties except:
questions.solution:
• Cisatracurium besylate.
  • Non-depolarising neuromuscular blocking drug, one of the 10 stereoisomers of atracurium (the 1R cis-1'R cis isomer; makes up 15% of atracurium, contribution about 60% of its activity).
  • Introduced in 1995, it causes minimal histamine release with cardiovascular stability. Also, although up to 70% metabolised by Hofmann elimination (cf. atracurium, 50-60%), produces about 10 times less laudanosine than atracurium after prolonged infusion, because of its greater potency and thus smaller total dosage.
  • Storage requirements are as for atracurium.
  • Faster degradation occurs when diluted in Hartmann's solution and 5% dextrose than in other iv fluids.

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 825

questions.text: The disinfecting action of chlorine is mainly due to:
questions.solution:
When chlorine is added to water, there is formation of hydrochloric and hypochlorous acids. The hydrochloric acid is neutralized by the alkalinity of the water. The hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen ions and hypochlorite ions, as follows:-

H2O + Cl2 → HCI + HOCl (hypochlorous acid)

HOCI → H + OCI (hypochlorite ion)

The disinfecting action of chlorine is mainly due to the hypochlorous acid, and to a small extent due to the hypochlorite ions. The hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine for water disinfection. It is more effective (70- 80 times) than the hypochlorite ion.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, page no 774

questions.text: A syndromic child comes to you for the first time. He has conotruncal cardiac lesion, hypoplastic thymus, hypocalcemia, abnormally increased B cells and low CD3+ T cells. Which of the following syndrome is likely?
questions.solution:
• Thymic hypoplasia results from dysmorphogenesis of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches during early embryogenesis, leading to hypoplasia or aplasia of the thymus and parathyroid glands.
  • Other features includes anomalies of the great vessels (right-sided aortic arch), esophageal atresia, bifid uvula, congenital heart disease (conotruncal, atrial, and ventricular septal defects), a short philtrum of the upper lip, hypertelorism, an antimongoloid slant to the eyes, mandibular hypoplasia, and low-set, often notched ears.
  • Hypocalcemic seizures during the neonatal period.
  • The CD3 T-cell counts are variably decreased in number, corresponding to the degree of thymic hypoplasia, resulting in an increased percentage of B cells.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition, Page no 1020

questions.text: Punishment for Perjury is defined under which IPC?
questions.solution:
191 I.P.C : Definition of perjury

193 I.P.C : Punishment for perjury

197 I.P.C : Punishment for issuance of false certificate

305 I.P.C : Punishment for abetment to suicide of child/insane

Reference: The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 55

questions.text: According to biomedical waste guidelines, 2016, the material for incineration should be discarded in which colour bag ?
questions.solution:
Non plastic infectious waste should be discarded in yellow bag and sent for incineration.

Biomedical waste guides are revised with time to time, most recent guidelines are as below.

Red bags or containers are used for infectious or biohazardous waste that poses a risk of infection.

Blue bags or containers are typically used for non-infectious waste that is not suitable for recycling.

Black bags or containers are meant for general non-hazardous waste.

Yellow bags or containers are used for waste that requires incineration, such as anatomical waste, pathological waste, and certain types of hazardous waste.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 12th edition, Page no 167

questions.text: Cryoprecipitate is a supernatant of FFP and rich in?
questions.solution:
Cryoprecipitate is a supernatant precipitate of FFP and is rich in fbrinogen, factor VIII and factor XIII. It is stored at −30°C with a 2-year shelf life. It is given in low-fbrinogen states or factor VIII defciency.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 21

questions.text: If you administer spinal anaesthesia with all the three spinal needles given in the image below, which one will provide you the most vigorous CSF flow?
questions.solution:
In the given image,

A- Quincke needle

B- Whitacre needle

C- Sprotte needle

The Sprotte is a side-injection needle with a long opening. It has the advantage of more vigorous CSF flow compared with similar gauge needles. However, this can lead to a failed block if the distal part of the opening is subarachnoid (with free flow CSF), the proximal part is not past the dura, and the full dose of medication is not delivered.

Quincke needle is a cutting needle with end injection.

The Whitacre and other pencil-point needles have rounded points and side injection which markedly decrease the incidence of post dural puncture headache.

Reference: Morgan and Mikhail's clinical anaesthesiology, 6th edition, page no 976

choices.text: It includes the infant mortality rate.
It does not include the GNP per capita.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) is false?
questions.solution:
The PQLI is scored from 0 to 100, not from 0 to 1.

It consolidates three indicators, viz. infant mortality (option B), life expectancy at age one, and literacy.

It may be mentioned that PQLI has not taken per capita GNP into consideration (option C), showing thereby that "money is not everything".

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, page no 17

questions.text: Most common pathogens responsible for nosocomial pneumonias in the ICU are?
questions.solution:
Pneumonia accounts for 15-20 % of nosocomial infections

Mortality due to ventilator associated pneumonia is 6-14 %

Precipitating factors for mortality include- Comorbidities and inadequate antibiotic treatment

Involvement of specific pathogens ( Particularly pseudomonas aeruginosa and Acinetobacter, which are gram negative)

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1009, 1019

choices.text: At birth the mammary glands in boys and girls are similar. At around 11-12 years of age, in girls the breast begins to grow. The onset of its growth is called 'the menarche' (1 year before thelarche).
An inverted nipple interferes with feeding and may become a source of infection by deposition of debris. It does not predispose to breast cancer.
Retraction of recent onset is always worrisome and may point towards an underlying carcinoma; however, the most common cause of long standing retraction is periductal mastitis

questions.text: All are true about nipple inversion and retraction except
questions.solution:
At birth the mammary glands in boys and girls are similar. At around 11-12 years of age, in girls the breast begins to grow. The onset of its growth is called 'the thelarche' (1 year before menarche). Initially uniform growth of cells leads to a rounded breast mound. Later elongation of the major milk ducts at age 14-16 years leads to projection of the nipple. Lack of elongation of the major milk ducts leads to failure of the nipple to protrude, called nipple inversion. An inverted nipple interferes with feeding and may become a source of infection by deposition of debris. It does not predispose to breast cancer.

Nipple retraction is an acquired phenomenon owing to fibrosis in and around the major milk ducts. Retraction of recent onset is always worrisome and may point towards an underlying carcinoma; however, the most common cause of long standing retraction is periductal mastitis

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 923

questions.text: 35 year old man is suffering from pneumonia. The sputum smear shows the following figure. Causative agent is.
questions.solution:
Acid fast ( Red colour) filamentous organism is Nocardia.

Nocardia is weakly gram positive catalase positive rod shaped bacteria. It forms partially acid fast beaded branching filaments. It contains a total of 85 species. Some species are non pathogenic, while others are responsible for nocardiosis.

Mostly it causes opportunistic infection in immunocompromised pt. Pulmonary nocardiosis and disseminated forms of the infection and opportunistic disease occur mainly in patients deficient in T cell mediated immunity.

Respiratory secretion, skin biopsy sample and aspirates from abscess are most common specimens from which nocardia species are identified.

Nocardia species can usually be isolated in 3-5 days.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, page no 400

questions.text: Psychotherapy of choice in OCD is-
questions.solution:
ERP stands for Exposure and Response Prevention. It is a type of cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) that is specifically designed to treat obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).

ERP involves gradually exposing the person with OCD to their feared stimuli, while preventing them from engaging in their compulsive behaviors. This helps the person to learn that the feared stimuli are not actually dangerous, and that they can tolerate the anxiety without resorting to their compulsions.

ERP is the most effective treatment for OCD, and it has been shown to be more effective than medication in many cases.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page no 596-597.

choices.text: Tumour limited to the nasopharyngeal cavity; bone destruction negligible or limited to the sphenopalatine foramen
Tumour invading the pterygopalatine fossa or the maxillary, ethmoid or sphenoid sinus with bone destruction
Tumour invading the infratemporal fossa or orbital region

questions.text: In Fisch classification for juvenile angiofibroma, type 2 indicates:
questions.solution:
The Fisch classification is a staging system for juvenile angiofibroma, a rare benign tumor that typically affects adolescent boys. The staging system is based on the extent of tumor spread and the presence or absence of bone destruction.

Type 1: Tumor limited to the nasopharyngeal cavity; bone destruction negligible or limited to the sphenopalatine foramen.

Type 2: Tumor invading the pterygopalatine fossa or the maxillary, ethmoid or sphenoid sinus with bone destruction.

Type 3: Tumor invading the infratemporal fossa or orbital region.

Type 4: Intracranial intradural tumor.

Reference: Scott-Brown's Otolaryngology: Head and Neck Surgery, 7th edition, volume 2, Page no 2439

questions.text: In this given figure area labelled '5' indicates
questions.solution:
• Tonsillar herniation is a type of brain herniation that occurs when the medial temporal lobe is forced through the tentorial incisura, which is a notch in the tentorium cerebelli. This can happen due to increased intracranial pressure, such as from a tumor or hydrocephalus.
  • In the image, you can see that the medial temporal lobe (the area labeled "5") has been forced through the tentorial incisura. This is causing compression of the brainstem, which can lead to a variety of symptoms, including headache, nausea, vomiting, and decreased consciousness.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page No 361

questions.text: A child presented with asymptomatic lesions on the forearm and on the shaft of penis, lesions on the forearm are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Lichen nitidus is a chronic disease with tiny, shiny, pinpoint papules in children.

The lesions are asymptomatic, present over penis, forearm, and extensors. Histopathology shows classical 'clutching the ball' appearance. Papillae are elongated and curved downwards and hold a collection of dermal lymphocytes and histiocytes within it.

Lichen planus presents with pruritic, polygonal, purple papules.

Scrofuloderma is cutaneous tuberculosis

Scabies is an itchy condition caused by infestation of mites.

Reference: Bolognia textbook of dermatology, 4th edition, page no 555-556

questions.text: A 32-week preterm baby is delivered by emergency CS due to severe PIH. 1 dose of betamethasone was given just before the CS. Child cried immediately after birth but developed respiratory distress and tachypnea within 1 hour of birth. The most likely diagnosis will be?
questions.solution:
• The child is preterm <34 week and 1 dose of Betamethasone is given just before delivery. This is not enough to stimulate the surfactant production. Atleast 12 hours of 2 doses of Betamethasone is must to have desired production of surfactant. Hence, the child is expected to be surfactant deficient. This goes with the condition of hyaline membrane disease.
  • Hyaline membrane disease presents with clinical features of respiratory distress and tachypnea within initial few hours of life. Some might also require active resuscitation.
  • TTN is a disease of full-term babies due to insufficient clearance of lung fluids.
  • BPD and PPHN does not present so early.

Reference: Cloherty and Stark's manual of newborn care, SA edition, page no 449

choices.text: Flaccidity of eyeball is one of the earliest signs
Tache Noir is seen with a retinoscope immediately after death
Kevorkian sign is the cattle trucking of blood in the retinal vasculature
Potassium levels in the vitreous show gradual and steady increase with time upto 100 hours after death.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about changes in eyes after death?
questions.solution:
Tache Noir : If the eyelids are open for a few hours after death, a film of cell debris and mucus forms two yellow triangles on the sclera at each side of the iris, with base towards the margin of cornea and apex towards medial or lateral canthus of the eye, which become brown and then black called "tache noir" within 3 to 4 hours, upon which dust settles and the surface becomes wrinkled (artefact).

Option A : The eyes look sunken and become softer within minutes due to reduction of intraocular tension.

Option C : Fragmentation or segmentation (tuking or shunting) of the blood columns (kevorkian sign) in the retinal vessels appear within minutes after death, and persists for about an hour. This occurs all over the body due to loss of blood pressure but it can be seen only in the retina by an ophthalmoscope.

Reference: The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology 33rd edition, Page no 153, 154

Agent causing acute bacterial prostatitis

It is most frequent caused by E Coli ( more than 50 %) followed by pseudomonas aeruginosa, and klebsiella enterococcus, enteroacter, proteus and serratia species.

This is caused by herpes zoster virus and is characterised by facial paralysis, pain and the appearance of vesicles on the tympanic membrane, ear canal, pinna or inside of the cheek. questions.text: Most sensitive index of recent transmission of malaria in community :

questions.text: False negative hydrostatic test in a live born fetus may be seen in -
questions.solution:
The hydrostatic test (Raygat's test): It is based on the fact that on breathing, the volume of the lungs is increased, which more than compensates the weight of the additional blood, due to which their specific gravity is diminished. The specific gravity of the lungs before respiration varies from 1040 to 1050, and after respiration about 940.

A ligature is tied on the bronchi, and lungs separated. Each lung individually is placed in water.

If they float, each lung is cut into twelve to twenty pieces and placed in water. A small piece of liver may serve as control.

If they float, they are each squeezed between thumb and index finger to remove the tidal air.

If all the pieces float, it indicates that the respiration has taken place.If all the pieces sink, it means the child has not breathed.

If some pieces sink and some pieces float, it indicates partial or feeble respiration.

Fallacies of hydrostatic test:

  • The expanded lungs may sink in cases of diseases such as acute edema, pneumonia, congenital syphilis, etc. or atelectasis (false negative)
  • The unexpanded lungs may float due to emphysema, putrefaction or artificial respiration (false positive)

Reference: The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 412

questions.text: Which of the following is not the beneficiary of prophylactic IFA supplements under Anemia Mukt Bharat ?
questions.solution:
The Anemia Mukt Bharat (Anemia Free India) program is a government initiative to reduce the prevalence of anemia in India. The program provides prophylactic iron-folate (IFA) supplements to school-going girls and women of reproductive age.

The program does not provide IFA supplements to out-of-school boys, as they are not considered to be at high risk of anemia. Out-of-school boys are more likely to have access to a varied diet, which reduces their risk of anemia.

questions.text: Identify the condition seen in the x ray of the baby
questions.solution:
The double bubble sign is a classic radiographic finding in duodenal atresia. It is caused by the accumulation of gas in the proximal duodenum and stomach. The gas-filled stomach and duodenum appear as two separate bubbles on the radiograph.

Duodenal atresia is a congenital condition in which the duodenum, the first part of the small intestine, is blocked. This blockage prevents food from passing from the stomach into the rest of the small intestine.

questions.text: 35-year-old male sustains the injury in his right leg, clinical image is shown below. On X-ray he has mid-shaft tibia and fibula fracture , he complains of painful "tightness" around the leg and severe uncontrolled pain. His pain is exacerbated when the toes and ankle are passively stretched in flexion and extension. What is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
This patient has clinical symptoms and signs of leg compartment syndrome and should undergo immediate fasciotomies of all 4 leg compartments, followed by external fixation for fracture stabilization.

Tibial fractures are among the most common reasons for compartment syndromes of the leg. A clinical assessment is key in the diagnosis of acute compartment syndrome. If there is uncertainty, intracompartmental pressure measurement has been advocated to help confirm the diagnosis.

5 p's of compartment syndrome pain out of proportion to exam, paralysis, paresthesias, pallor, pulselessness

We can not perform intramedullary nailing or open reduction and internal fixation in this case because surgery itself is a predisposing factor for development of compartment syndrome

Trichinellosis

questions.text: You are intubating a patient received after poly trauma. He is suspected to have cervical spine injury. What is the manoeuvre being performed?
questions.solution:
When manipulating the airway, correct patient positioning is very helpful. Relative alignment of the oral and pharyngeal axes is achieved by having the patient in the 'sniffing' position. When cervical spine pathology is suspected, the head must be kept in a neutral position during all airway manipulations. In-line stabilization of the neck must be maintained during airway management in these patients, unless appropriate cervical radiographs have been reviewed and cleared by an appropriate specialist.

choices.text: Have a written infant feeding policy that is routinely communicated to staff and parents

Establishment of ongoing monitoring and data-management system
Facilitate immediate and uninterrupted skin to skin contact and support mothers to initiate breastfeeding within 4 hours after birth

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Baby Friendly Hospital Initiative:
questions.solution:
Facilitate immediate and uninterrupted skin to skin contact and support mothers to initiate breastfeeding as soon as possible (not within 4 hours) after birth.

The ten steps of BFHI are : (la) Comply fully with the international code of marketing of breast-milk substitutes and relevant World Health Assembly resolutions; (lb) Have a written infant feeding policy that is routinely communicated to staff and parents; (lc) Establish ongoing monitoring and data-management system;

(2) Ensure that staff have sufficient knowledge, competence and skills to support

breastfeeding;

(3) Discuss the importance and management of breastfeeding with pregnant women and their families;

(4) Facilitate immediate and uninterrupted skin to skin contact and support mothers to initiate breastfeeding as soon as possible after birth;

(5) Support mothers to initiate and maintain breastfeeding and manage common difficulties,

(6) Do not provide breastfed newborns any food or fluids other than breast milk, unless medically indicated;

(7) Enable mothers and their infants to remain together and to practice rooming-in 24 hours a day;

(8) Support mothers to recognize and respond to their infant's cues for feeding;

(9) Counsel mothers on the use and risk of feeding bottles, teats and pacifiers;

(10) Coordinate discharge so that parents and their infants have timely access to ongoing support and care

questions.text: Control of haemorrhage and control of contamination is done under which stage of damage control surgery ?
questions.solution:
Damage control surgery (DCS) is a surgical approach used in patients with severe injuries who are at risk of death from exsanguination or infection. DCS is a two-stage process:

Stage I: The surgeon focuses on controlling hemorrhage and contamination. This may involve packing wounds, clamping vessels, or performing temporary repairs.

Stage II: The patient is stabilized and then taken back to the operating room for definitive repair of the injuries.

questions.text: All of the following statements about the 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPV23) are true except:
questions.solution:
Local reactions are more frequent in recipients of the 2nd dose of the vaccine, not the 1st dose.

Children under 2 years of age do not respond well to the vaccine (option A), as it induces T-cell independent immunity which is poorly developed at less than 2 years of age.

The vaccine should not be mixed in the same syringe with other vaccines, for e.g. with influenza vaccine, but may be administered at the same time by separate injection in the other arm.

PPV23 is recommended for selected groups, e.g., those who have undergone splenectomy (option D) or have sickle-cell disease, chronic diseases of heart, lung, liver or kidney; diabetes mellitus, alcoholism, generalized malignancies, organ transplants etc. In some industrialized countries like USA it is routinely advised for everyone aged above 65 years.

HLA complex

The histocompatibility antigen ( Human leukocyte antigen) is a cell surface antigen that induces an immune response leading to rejection of allograft.

HLA is also known as the MHC complex.

There are 3 types

MHC Class 1

  • Comprising A,B, C loci

  • Found on surface of all nucleated cells and platelet

MHC class 2

  • Responsible for Graft versus host response
  • Mixed leukocyte reaction
  • Found only on cells of immune system

MHC class 3

  • C2, C4
  • Properdin Factor B

  • TNF alpha and Beta
  • Enzyme 21-hydroxylase

questions.text: A researcher studying physician behavior is interested in how often primary care physicians take the sexual histories of patients during clinic visits. As part of the study, patients who attend a primary care clinic are asked to fill out a questionnaire immediately following a visit with their physician. Once the physicians become aware that their own behavior is being studied, which of the following is most likely to be a potential problem?
questions.solution:
Hawthorne effect (observer effect) is the tendency of study subjects to change their behavior as a result of their awareness that they are being studied This can impact the observed outcomes, thereby seriously affecting the validity of the study. The Hawthome effect is commonly seen in studies concerning behavioral outcomes or outcomes that can be influenced by behavioral changes. In this example, physicians (not patients) are the subjects of the study, those physicians who are aware that they are being studied may modify their behavior and start taking sexual histories: To minimize the Hawthorne effect, study subjects can be kept unaware that they are being studied, but this can occasionally pose ethical problems.

Option a : Attrition bias refers to bias secondary to lost to follow up in case of cohort studies.

Option b: Berkson's bias refers to selection bias created by choosing hospitalized patients as the contral group.

Optiopn D: Pygmalion effect describes the fact that a researcher's beliefs in the efficacy of treatment can potentially affect the outcome In the classic classroom experiment that first described the Pygmalion effect, a group of students were randomly assigned high intelligence quotient (IQ) scores, their teachers were then told of these artificial results and had higher expectations of this group as a result The students with the randomly assigned high IQ scores actually performed better, likely because their teachers unconsciously behaved in a manner that would facilitate their success.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th Edition, Page no 81,82

questions.text: A child presents with vesicles in the mouth (as shown below) and a rash on the hands and feet. What is the causative organism for it?
questions.solution:
Coxsackievirus A16 is part of group of coxsackieviruses related to enteroviruses that belong to the picornaviridaae family of non enveloped linear, positive sense single stranded RNA viruses. As well as its genum enterovirus which includes polio virus and echovirus. Coxsackie virus A16 typically most common cause of hand, foot and mouth disease in the USA. It is very contagious. They can pass from person to person on unwashed hands and contaminated surface. They can spread through droplets of fluid sprayed in to the air when a person sneeze or coughs. Treatment includes staying home, getting rest and drinking plenty of fluids.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is strongly associated with developing myositis ossificans?

questions.text: According to Hinchey classification of complicated diverticulitis 'pelvic abscess' is which grade ?

Hinchey classification is a system for grading the severity of complicated diverticulitis. It is based on the extent of inflammation and infection, as well as the presence or absence of perforation.

Grade I: Localised inflammation with no perforation.

Grade II: Pelvic abscess.

Grade III: Free perforation with generalized peritonitis.

Grade IV: Perforation with walled-off abscess

choices.text: State Government's share of expenditure on medical care is 1/8 of total cost of medical care; the ESI Corporation's share of expenditure on medical care is 7/8 of total cost of medical care.

questions.text: Which of following is incorrect regarding ESI act?
questions.solution:
The Union Minister for Labour is the Chairman and the Secretary to Govt. of India Ministry of Labour is the Vice-Chairman of this corporation.

Salient features of ESI act:

  • The ESI Act covers all power-using factories other than seasonal factories wherein 10 or more persons were employed (excluding mines, railways and defence establishments).
  • Medical benefit consists of 'full medical care' including hospitalization, free of cost, to the insured persons in case of sickness, employment injury and maternity.
  • The Sickness benefit is payable for a maximum period of 91 days, in any continuous period of 365 days, the daily rate being about 70% of the average daily wages.
  • Extended sickness benefit: In addition to 91 days of sickness benefit, insured persons suffering from certain long-term diseases are entitled to Extended Sickness Benefit, for a maximum period of two years.
  • Enhanced sickness benefit is payable to insured women for 14 days for tubectomy and for 7 days in case of vasectomy in respect of male IPs. The amount payable equal to full wages.
  • Disability benefits: The rate of temporary disablement benefit is about 90 percent of the wages as long as the temporary disablement lasts.
  • In case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependants of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90 per cent of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share.
  • Funeral benefit is a cash payment payable on the death of an insured person towards the expenses on his funeral, the amount not exceeding Rs. 15,000/-
  • On monthly payment of Rs 10, the insured person and his family members continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement, or retirement.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, page no 913

His food intake was also decreased. His stool was collected and sent to lab. Where motility testing was done. In report it was written non motile organism identified. Shigella dysentery is non motile organism among given options. Motility occurs because of flagella in bacteria. Arrangement of flagella varies from bacteria to bacteria. It may be monotrichos, peritrichous, lophotrichos and amphitrichous.

choices.text: May be inserted after exploration of the common bile duct and stone retrieval or following repair of a damaged common bile duct
The principle is to allow bile to drain while the sphincter of Oddi is in spasm postoperatively and to act as a safety valve if there are any stones retained in the distal common bile duct
Once inserted, a T-tube should remain in place for at least 2-3 days
Before removal, a T-tube cholangiogram should demonstrate the free flow of bile into the duodenum with no retained stones or bile leak. The T-tube is then clamped for 24 hours and removed.

questions.text: All are true about the following except
questions.solution:
A T-tube may be inserted after exploration of the common bile duct and stone retrieval or following repair of a damaged common bile duct.

The principle is to allow bile to drain while the sphincter of Oddi is in spasm postoperatively and to act as a safety valve if there are any stones retained in the distal common bile duct.

Once inserted, a T-tube should remain in place for at least 2-3 weeks to encourage fistulous tract formation, thereby minimising the risk of biliary peritonitis after removal of the T-tube. Before removal, a T-tube cholangiogram should demonstrate the free flow of bile into the duodenum with no retained stones or bile leak. The T-tube is then clamped for 24 hours and removed. The T-tube is clamped to allow preferential drainage of bile to the duodenum; if there is no distal obstruction the patient will be asymptomatic. Once the T-tube is removed, there will be minimal bile leakage through the fistulous tract for a few days. This should stop as a fistula will close if there is no distal obstruction.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 115, 116

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Global Hunger Index?
questions.solution:
The Global Hunger Index (GHI) is a tool that measures the level of hunger in a country. It is a composite index that takes into account three indicators:

  • Undernourishment: The percentage of the population that is undernourished, meaning that they do not have enough to eat to meet their daily energy needs.
  • Child wasting: The percentage of children under the age of 5 who are too thin for their height, a sign of acute malnutrition.
  • Child stunting: The percentage of children under the age of 5 who are too short for their age, a sign of chronic malnutrition.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, page no 791

questions.text: A 25 years old female complains of recurrent rhinitis, nasal discharge and bilateral nasal blockage for one year. She has a history of asthma and allergy. On examination multiple ethmoidal polyps are noted with mucosal thickening and impacted secretions in both the nasal cavities. Biopsy is taken and the material is cultured which shows the growth of many hyphae and pseudohyphae with dichotomous branching typically at 45°. Which of the following is the most likely responsible organism?
questions.solution:
Information provided in this question are: -

i) Recurrent rhinitis, nasal discharge, bilateral nasal blockage.

ii) H/O asthma and allergy

iii) Hyphae with dichotomous branching at 45°C.

All suggest the diagnosis of Aspergillus fumigatus.

i) Most common type of fungal infection of the nose and paranasal sinuses are due to aspergillus.

ii) Most common fungus causing allergy is aspergillus.

iii) Aspergillus has septate hyphae that branch typically at 45°C (V shaped).

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 18th Edition, Page no 1655, 1656

questions.text: Which of the following condition is similar to mild atrophic rhinitis?
questions.solution:
Rhinitis sicca is a condition which is similar to mild atrophic rhinitis without progressing to its full clinical picture. This is a widespread condition, frequent in those engaged in dry, hot and dusty occupations, and is also caused by a variety of other factors such as alcoholism, anaemia, nutritional and constitutional diseases.

Reference: Scott-Brown's Otolaryngology: Head and Neck Surgery, 7th edition, volume 2, Page no 1466

choices.text: This condition mostly occurs between 2 months and 2 years

An air enema is treatment of choice if there is peritonitis , perforation or shock

questions.text: A previously healthy infant presents with colicky pain, vomiting and drawing up their legs. Between episodes, they initially appear well. Later, they may pass a 'redcurrant jelly' stool. Signs include dehydration, abdominal distension and a palpable right upper quadrant mass.On exploration, all are true about the condition seen in the picture except
questions.solution:
Most intussusceptions occur between 2 months and 2 years. More than 80% are ileocolic, beginning proximal to the ileocaecal valve with an apex in the ascending or transverse colon. Strangulation can progress to gangrene and perforation. The lead point is commonly viral-induced hyperplasia in a Peyer's patch, but a few have a pathological lead such as a Meckel's diverticulum, duplication cyst or a small bowel lymphoma. Pathological leads are found more commonly in those over 2 years and in a recurrence.

A plain radiograph shows small bowel obstruction, a mass and a paucity of gas in the right iliac fossa. A concentric target sign is seen on an abdominal ultrasound. An air reduction enema is attempted after resuscitation with intravenous fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics and nasogastric drainage. Success is recognised if air flows into the small bowel and symptoms and signs resolve. An air enema is contraindicated if there is peritonitis, perforation or shock. More than 70% are reducible non-operatively.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 260
