questions.text: Which fibers of the anterior cruciate ligament are tight in flexion?
questions.solution:
There are two bundles of the anterior cruciate ligament, the anteromedial and posterolateral. The anteromedial bundle is tight in flexion; in extension, all fibers are tensioned.

Reference: Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th Edition, Page 574, 575

questions.text: A 40 year old presented with oral erosions and fluid filled lesions as shown in the image. On investigation, skin biopsy shows suprabasal cleft with row of tombstone appearance and antibodies against Dsg 1 and Dsg 3 were positive. What will be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Essentially all patients with pemphigus vulgaris develop painful erosions of the oral mucosa. More than half of the patients also develop flaccid blisters and widespread cutaneous erosions
  • Those with the mucocutaneous type of pemphigus vulgaris have both anti-Dsg3 and anti-Dsg1 IgG autoantibodies location of the split is suprabasal, the presence of acantholytic cells, and the 'tombstones' appearance of the basal cells in seen on skin biopsy.

Reference: Bologna textbook of dermatology, 4th edition, page no 503

questions.text: 11 years old child has abdominal pain and palpable purpura on back and legs. What would be the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
• The child in the question has typical features of Henoch Schonlein Purpura.
  • Steroids are most often used to treat significant gastrointestinal involvement or other life-threatening manifestations. Prednisone (1 mg/kg/day for 1-2 weeks, followed by tapered doses) reduces abdominal and joint pain but does not alter overall prognosis nor prevent renal disease.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition, Page no no 1218

questions.text: E. Histocytica. True are
questions.solution:
1. histolytica and E. dispar, Compared and Contrasted

Similarities

  1. Both species are spread through ingestion of infectious cysts.
  2. Cysts of the two species are morphologically identical.
  3. Both species colonise the large intestine

Differences

  1. Only E. histolytica causes invasive disease.
  2. Only E. histolytica infections elicit a positive amebic serology
  3. The two species have distinct rRNA sequences
  4. The two species have distinct surface antigens and isoenzyme markers
  5. Gal/GalNAc lectin can be used to differentiate the two species in stool ELISA

-The most common type of amebic infection is asymptomatic cyst passage

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 17th Edition, Page no 1275

However, severe burns or burns to large areas of the hand can be subsequently treated with Bier's blocks containing calcium gluconate 10% gel
It is best to split skin graft these HF wounds initially but not in the delayed stage

questions.text: All are true about the hydrofluoric acid burn except
questions.solution:
One acid that is a common cause of acid burns is hydrofuoric acid, although generally a weak acid, it chelates calcium and magnesium in tissues. Burns affecting the fingers and caused by dilute acid are relatively common. The initial management is with calcium gluconate gel topically; however, severe burns or burns to large areas of the hand can be subsequently treated with Bier's blocks containing calcium gluconate 10% gel. If the patient has been burnt with a concentration greater than 50%, the threat of hypocalcaemia and subsequent arrhythmias then becomes high, and this is an indication for acute early excision. It is best not to split-skin graft these hydrofluoric acid wounds initially, but to do this at a delayed stage.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 680

questions.text: Which of the following is not the approach to health education?
questions.solution:
4 Basic approaches of health education are

  1. Regulatory approach
  2. Service approach
  3. Health education approach
  4. Primary health care approach

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, page no 954/955

questions.text: Sweating is not seen in -
questions.solution:
• Heat stroke is a condition characterized by a rectal temperature greater than 41°C, and neurological disturbances.
  • Sweating is not seen in heat stroke.
  • Heat cramps are caused by a rapid dehydration of body through the loss of water and salt in the sweat.
  • Heat syncope is a condition of collapse without increase in body temperature, which follows exposure to excessive heat.

Reference: The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 296

Fauces, soft palate with some part of uvula seen

questions.text: According to mallampati test as modified by samsoon and young grade 4 is :
questions.solution:
The Mallampati test is a clinical assessment of the airway that is used to predict the difficulty of laryngoscopy and intubation. The test is graded on a scale of 1 to 4, with 1 being the easiest and 4 being the most difficult.

In Grade 4 of the Mallampati test, the soft palate and uvula are not visible at all. Only the hard palate is visible. This indicates that the airway is likely to be difficult to manage.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition Page No 287.

questions.text: A 25 year old lady came to hospital with high grade fever, increased frequency of micturition and burning micturition for 3 days. Urine was sent to the lab and it showed plenty of pus cells. What is the most common organism causing this condition in the community?
questions.solution:
E coli causes 80 % of acute UTI in patients without catheter. It is commonest cause of UTI in community

Proteus: it causes UTI but it is not the commonest cause in community

Pseudomonas: it causes UTI but it is not the commonest cause in community

Streptococci: Streptococcus rarely cause UTI

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, page no 11

questions.text: Most important / significant and most difficult bradforth hill criteria of causality is , respectively
questions.solution:
Most important hill criteria: Temporality of association (eg. A followed B )

Most difficult hill criteria to establish: Specificity (Eg. Lung Cancer is not only specific to smoking )

Nine bradforth hill crieteria of causality:

  1. Strength : A small association does not mean that there is not a causal effect, though the larger the association, the more likely that it is causal.
  2. Consistency (reproducibility): Consistent findings observed by different persons in different places with different samples strengthens the likelihood of an effect.
  3. Specificity: Causation is likely if there is a very specific population at a specific site and disease with no other likely explanation. The more specific an association between a factor and an effect is, the bigger the probability of a causal relationship.
  4. Temporality: The effect has to occur after the cause (and if there is an expected delay between the cause and expected effect, then the effect must occur after that delay).
  5. Biological gradient (dose-response relationship): Greater exposure should generally lead to greater incidence of the effect. However, in some cases, the mere presence of the factor can trigger the effect. In other cases, an inverse proportion is observed: greater exposure leads to lower incidence.
  6. Plausibility: A plausible mechanism between cause and effect is helpful (but Hill noted that knowledge of the mechanism is limited by current knowledge).
  7. Coherence: Coherence between epidemiological and laboratory findings increases the likelihood of an effect. However, Hill noted that "lack of such [laboratory] evidence cannot nullify the epidemiological effect on associations".
  8. Experiment: "Occasionally it is possible to appeal to experimental evidence".
  9. Analogy: The use of analogies or similarities between the observed association and any other associations.

Reference : Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, page no 97

questions.text: A lady with 38 weeks pregnancy and painless vaginal bleeding comes to casualty. On examination the head is engaged and the uterus is non-tender and relaxed. The next line of treatment is:
questions.solution:
• Painless vaginal bleeding and absence of other significant findings confirm the diagnosis of placenta previa.
  • Gestational age of the patient is 38 weeks i.e. fetal maturity is attained so termination should be done.
  • In case of severe, bleeding pregnancy is terminated by cesarean section irrespective of gestational age.
  • Note: Here I have ruled out option a i.e. per speculum examination because in case of placenta previa a double set up examination (i.e. examination in OT) is done and not simple P/S or P/V.

Reference: Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 7th edition, page no 249, 250

questions.text: Streptococcus is a medically important bacteria. It causes many diseases in the human body, some of them are fatal. C carbohydrate in streptococcus hemolyticus is important for.
questions.solution:
Hemolytic Streptococci were classified by lancefield serological classification into groups based on nature of C carbohydrate antigen on the cell wall. These are known as lancefield groups, twenty of which have been identified so far and named A to V (without I and J)

Phagocytic inhibition: it not used for phagocytic inhibition

Toxin production: it is not used for toxin production

Hemolysis: it is not used for haemolysis.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, page no 209

questions.text: Identify the suture technique seen in following picture
questions.solution:
A subcuticular suture is a type of suture that is placed entirely within the subcutaneous tissue. This type of suture is often used to close skin incisions, as it leaves no visible suture marks.

In the image, you can see that the suture is placed in a continuous loop, with each stitch being buried under the previous stitch. This creates a smooth, uninterrupted line of sutures that is invisible from the outside.

Subcuticular sutures are typically removed after 5-7 days.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 108

questions.text: A child was treated for PEM but during rehabilitation developed refeeding syndrome. Which of the following is the most characteristic feature in a child with refeeding syndrome?
questions.solution:
• When excessive carbohydrates are administered, the resultant increase in serum insulin levels may produce hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia, and hypomagnesemia. The hallmark of refeeding syndrome is the development of severe hypophosphatemia after the cellular uptake of phosphate during the 1st week of starting to reefed.

Reference: Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 20th edition, page no 306

questions.text: Potential threat with Jhunjhunia seed adulteration is:
questions.solution:
Studies conducted by the National Institute of Nutrition, Hyderabad showed that the local population subsist on the millet Panicum miliare (known locally as Gondhli) which gets contaminated with weed seeds of Crotalaria (locally known as Jhunjhunia). On chemical analysis. Jhunjhunia seeds were found to contain pyrrolizidine alkaloids which are hepatotoxins. The preventive measures comprise educating the people in the affected areas about the disease, deweeding of the Jhunjhunia plants which grow along with the staple, and simple sieving of the millet at the household level to remove the seeds of Jhunjhunia which are considerably smaller than those of the millet.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, page no 747

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with numbness of both hands. The patient was asked to perform the test demonstrated. What is the name of the test?
questions.solution:
• The Roos test is a provocative test for diagnosis of thoracic outlet syndrome.
  • The patient stands and abducts the shoulder to 90 degrees, externally rotates the shoulder, and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees.
  • The patient then opens and closes the hand slowly for three minutes.
  • The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experience heaviness, numbness, tingling or pain.
  • The Roos test is also known as the elevated arm stress test (EAST).

Here are some other tests that are used to diagnose thoracic outlet syndrome:

  • Adson's test
  • Wright hyperabduction test
  • Pemberton's test

Reference: Apley's system of Orthopedics and Fracture, 9th Edition, Page no 293

questions.text: Which immunoglobulin crosses placenta ?
questions.solution:
Antibody transfer across placenta

  • Most of you must be knowing that only IgG can cross the placenta, but how many of you know the reason for this.

Lets see:-

IgG exists as a monomer in the plasma → can cross the placenta.

IgM is a pentamer (large size) → cannot cross the placenta.

IgA exists as a dimer and is mostly localised to mucosal layer → cannot cross placenta (note- serum IgA is a monomer but most of the IgA is localised to mucosal layers)

IgD is bound to the surface of B cells →→ B cells do not cross placenta

IgE is in very very low levels in the plasma and mostly bound by eosinophils.

So, only IgG crosses the placenta.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th edition, Page no 99

questions.text: Iceberg phenomenon is not seen in:
questions.solution:
In some diseases (e.g., hypertension, diabetes, anaemia, malnutrition, mental illness) the unknown morbidity (i.e., the submerged portion of the iceberg) far exceeds the known morbidity. The hidden part of the iceberg thus constitutes an important, undiagnosed reservoir of infection or disease in the community, and its detection and control is a challenge to modern techniques in preventive medicine. One of the major deterrents in the study of chronic diseases of unknown aetiology is the absence of methods to detect the subclinical state - the bottom of the iceberg.

Iceberg phenomenon does not apply in Acute disease like Rabies ,Tetanus.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, page no 46

questions.text: A girl with a growing lump in her neck. She has freckles and flat spots on face and body. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Neurofibromas are benign tumors that develop from nerve tissue. They are often associated with a genetic disorder called neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1).

People with NF1 typically have multiple neurofibromas, as well as other features such as freckles, flat spots on the skin, and bone deformities.

Neurofibromas can grow anywhere in the body, but they are most common on the skin, in the peripheral nerves, and in the brain.

They are usually painless, but they can sometimes grow large enough to cause pressure on nerves or other structures.

Treatment for neurofibromas is usually not necessary unless they are causing problems. In some cases, surgery may be used to remove large or symptomatic neurofibromas.

Reference : Bolognia's Dermatology: An illustrated textbook, 4th edition, page no 1432-1433

questions.text: 11 years old child with rheumatic fever has fever and sore throat. His heart evaluation was normal. How long should he receive Benzathine penicillin prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Children with rheumatic fever and a normal heart evaluation should receive long-term prophylaxis with Benzathine penicillin to prevent recurrent episodes of rheumatic fever and further damage to the heart valves. The recommended duration of Benzathine penicillin prophylaxis in such cases is 5 years or until 21 years of age, whichever is longer.

Reference Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition, Page no 1336

questions.text: A 45 year old farmer complains of fever, night sweat and weight loss. Upon asking he said he has an evening rise of fever. He has a history of smoking 25 bidis per day for the last 20 years. Primary complex of M bovis involves?
questions.solution:
The primary complex of M tuberculosis (Inf by inhalation).

  1. Lung lesion
  2. Enlarged hilar lymph nodes

Primary complex of M bovis (inf by drinking milk).

  1. Tonsil
  2. Cervical node or intestine (Ileocecal region and mesenteric lymph nodes)

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 354

questions.text: Under the National AIDS Control Programme, kit 1 (grey) is used for syndromic management of all of the following complaints except:
questions.solution:
Lower abdominal pain is treated with kit 6 (yellow).

Cervical discharge (option A), painful scrotal swelling (option B) and urethral discharge (option C) are all treated with kit 1 (grey).

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 472

questions.text: A 42 yr old patient, singer by profession has been vigorously practising for an important concert of his life. He has subsequently developed hoarse voice. On fiberoptic laryngoscopy, he is found to have adduction of false vocal cords while phonating. What is the name of this clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Dysphonia plica ventricularis (ventricular dysphonia) -

  • Here voice is produced by ventricular folds (false cords) which have taken over the function of true cords.
  • Voice is rough, low pitched and unpleasant.
  • Indirect laryngoscopy- false cords are seem to approximate partially or completely
  • It is of two types -
    • Functional type - psychogenic. Here voice begins normally but soon becomes rough.
    • Secondary to laryngeal disorders.

Reference - Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th edition, Pg no 366.
